story:
Tarot of Unknown Shadows.



Tarot of Unknown Shadows is made by using a technique of a collage - a truly alchemy art of our time. By assembling different parts of old photographs from 19th and early 20th century the infinite possibilities of time and space travelling are open for us. Every cutted part hides its own memory, traces of previous experience, destinies, desires, carries multiple sequences of connections and progressions of the past. Thus, the total sum of all these fragments, no matter how small, large or irregular they are unfold the hidden content into the future. By reading it we indeed rip a hole in the fabric of reality.

 

 

 

What is Dark Synevyr?

 

Synevyr is an extraordinary lake appeared ten thousands years ago in the Carpathian Mountains. A mysterious place nature tries to hide, a place glowing with its sacredness. Dark sky above and its reflection on the water gives us a certain secret knowledge. With the inspiration we draw from it this implicit energy transforms into our work.

 

The Fool. Tarot of Unknow Shadows.

The Magician. Tarot of Unknow Shadows.

The Hight Priestess. Tarot of Unknow Shadows.

List of our Indiegogo Campaigns:

1. The Manuscript of Initiation Tarot

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/the-manuscri...

2. PinkPain Tarot 

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/pinkpain-tar...

3. Paracelsus' Dreams Tarot

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/paracelsus-d...

For a full view of the image, see the original full sized image HERE

Once you buy a slot, please note Wen on FA with which slot you purchased and the email address associated with your donation, your character references, and any other details requested in the Perks! Thank you!

Short Summary

Artists Wen & Tato have been serving the babyfur community for over two years, providing adorable art for the young at heart. This month, we're doing a fun Summer themed fundraiser for St Jude Children's Research Hospital!

Rules & Info

We're asking for you to buy a slot in this Your Character Here Summer image. Here's what you'll get:

  • Your character gets featured in the slot # of your choice!
  • You choose your outfit
  • Fan characters are permitted
  • Must provide full color references
  • Age & body type are a fixed aspect

The Impact

100% of the proceeds will go to St Jude Children's Research Hospital. If you've ever enjoyed the colorful art that comes from the babyfur community, take this chance to give back to needy children and make their Summer  one to remember!

Other Ways You Can Help

Any donations are accepted towards this cause! All donators' names will be mentioned & linked to in the final image to be posted at FurAffinity.net (Please provide your FurAffinity screename when you donate!)

story:
Show off your voyages and inspire new heights of imagination with this gorgeous set of 14 Vintage Space Travel Posters with artwork created by NASA. 

NASA recently commissioned and released a gorgeous series of 14 retro-themed space travel posters to inspire a generation to reach for the stars and live in a world where space travel is within reach of all mankind. 

We fell in love with these designs and realized there was not an easy way for the average person to have these in museum quality prints and we wanted to find a way to display them  in our homes, offices and businesses. As a citizen of planet earth, we've been graciously given permission to create a series of products with these images.

We are running a campaign to create the highest quality prints and travel journals so you can enjoy these beautiful images until the day comes that you can actually get to space. 

 We are producing a limited collection run of softcover, matte finish travel journals featuring these 14 space travel posters as the covers. Select them individually or all 14, these are certain to be great travel companions for you.

Impress your friends, family and co-workers with these museum quality prints. Constructed of only the highest quality archival paper and inks and printed, assembled and shipped from our 100% Sweatshop free design studio in Los Angeles. 

 You'll be the envy of your next star gazing potluck with the rich, vibrant colors of these dreamscapes adoring the walls of your home or office.

 For the more ambitious adventurer, we've created complete collections of all 14 prints, both frame-ready and framed in 3 sizes. 

The poster artwork in this project is used with permission from The NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory in compliance with the generous JPL Image Use Policy. This independent project is not endorsed nor affiliated with NASA, JPL or Caltech in anyway.

Our project logo includes vector elements designed by Freepik and used with permission.

Video music track is Montreal by KJ Sawka, used with permission via Animoto.

Risks and challenges

We've confirmed the use & image rights with NASA and sourced production and fulfillment to our world class partners. We are on track to have the all backer rewards shipped by May 31st, 2016.
story_txt:
Show off your voyages and inspire new heights of imagination with this gorgeous set of 14 Vintage Space Travel Posters with artwork created by NASA. NASA recently commissioned and released a gorgeous series of 14 retro-themed space travel posters to inspire a generation to reach for the stars and live in a world where space travel is within reach of all mankind. We fell in love with these designs and realized there was not an easy way for the average person to have these in museum quality prints and we wanted to find a way to display them  in our homes, offices and businesses. As a citizen of planet earth, we've been graciously given permission to create a series of products with these images.We are running a campaign to create the highest quality prints and travel journals so you can enjoy these beautiful images until the day comes that you can actually get to space. 


14 gorgeous retro space travel posters, ready for your private collection.

 We are producing a limited collection run of softcover, matte finish travel journals featuring these 14 space travel posters as the covers. Select them individually or all 14, these are certain to be great travel companions for you.



Impress your friends, family and co-workers with these museum quality prints. Constructed of only the highest quality archival paper and inks and printed, assembled and shipped from our 100% Sweatshop free design studio in Los Angeles. 


Framed prints in three sizes.
 You'll be the envy of your next star gazing potluck with the rich, vibrant colors of these dreamscapes adoring the walls of your home or office.


Frame-ready museum quality prints.
 For the more ambitious adventurer, we've created complete collections of all 14 prints, both frame-ready and framed in 3 sizes. 


Complete set of 14 prints, frame-ready or framed, in 3 sizes.












The poster artwork in this project is used with permission from The NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory in compliance with the generous JPL Image Use Policy. This independent project is not endorsed nor affiliated with NASA, JPL or Caltech in anyway.Our project logo includes vector elements designed by Freepik and used with permission.Video music track is Montreal by KJ Sawka, used with permission via Animoto.
Risks and challengesWe've confirmed the use & image rights with NASA and sourced production and fulfillment to our world class partners. We are on track to have the all backer rewards shipped by May 31st, 2016.

story:
The Edward Snowden Monument Project

We the citizens of the world wish to erect a monument to Edward Snowden in all 50 US states. We need your help to raise money and to work with local municipalities to build Edward Snowden monuments all over the country.

story:
Life of "Second Wind Tarot"

Thurs,Jan 21st, 2010 I had my surgery. Although the photos on my "near death link" are really hard to look at I need anyone who wants to be educated about Parasitic Fibroid Tumors and to take a look so they can know what to expect. I was scheduled for a routine two day surgery for fibroid removal and a hysterectomy. 
The tumor was suppose to be the size of a few grapefruits. As you can see to our surprise my doctor was not ready.  I laid cut open on the operation table for five hours waiting for the other specialty surgeons to arrive to remove the tumors from my vital organs. These photos are just the top half of the tumors they had encased all my major organs, kidneys, colon, femoral artery in my left leg and split my bladder in half.  I was in the hospital for 9 days, I lost 11 bags of blood and had to be intubated for 4 days. I went from a routine 2 day hysterectomy to 9 days in critical  care and ICU. I wore a urine bag do to my bladder needing to be reconstructed with stints added. Everyday  I will answer questions & write to help anyone who is facing this procedure or who knows someone that is going to go thru this experience to be better prepared. 

I had all these dreams and visions of tarot cards during this experience, some would say it was because I was in a lucid state which inspired me to create "Second Wind Tarot" deck. I vowed if God gave me a "Second Wind" I would create this deck and dedicate it to my new life. Everyday I committed to help all who is facing a procedure or anyone who knows someone that is going to go thru this experience to be better prepared.

Near Death - For those of you that are not that squeamish. These photos are just the top half of the tumors they had encased all my major organs, kidneys, colon, femoral artery in my left leg and split my bladder in half. 

After my surgery I designed this deck and moved back to California and currently live as a professional Spiritual Teacher/Tarot Reader and artist. My reputation has been time tested for accuracy and honesty. My clientele list ranges from an exclusive mix of the elite in the Film/Television and Music Industry to the my family, friends and co-workers.  I began my instruction at a very early age, I have researched and practiced the art using clairvoyance and intuition. Using art and tarot I specialize in helping others to understand how energy works and what road they are currently walking on in their relationships, career, home, and spiritual path, as well as helping clients to see where those paths are taking them in the future.




What We Need & What You Get

My team and I need 5,500 to print, launch and market & promote Second Wind Tarot.  Approximately $3700 to $4000 alone is needed for the printing cost of 500 shrink rapped sets of both the cards and the custom tuck boxes. The remaining monies will be going to direct mail, social media, also new age bookstores and gift shops as well as other promotions.  No matter what, if you choose a perk that receives a deck *you will get one*. 



Perks, perks and more perks!! 

Please check out my great perks on the right.

You will get a full deck of 78 cards with interpretations, which include 22 Majors and 56 Lessor/Minor cards to print the actual booklet will take another campaign. The decks will be ordered at the end of the campaign and the printing will talk 6-8 weeks. Add another week for shipping. As soon as I get the shipment they will go out to you!




The Impact

I've had a lot of interest in the cards ever since I first started. People have been asking when the set will be available to buy - many want to buy a set as a gift for their friends and loved ones! The cards have definitely aroused the strongest emotional response of all my artwork and it would be a shame not to see them produced!

I believe in this deck so much, Ive used my own money over the years to produce the spec of about $1500. I have no other funding sources, so if I don't reach my target amount then I'll have to hussle myself to friends and family to invest the remaining amount. I'm determined to get this project off the ground one way or another, but without support I may have to shelve the project indefinitely.

I believe it is necessary to help people understand how visual art/energy works and affects them in the universe. How everyone has the ability to help himself or herself succeed themselves by understanding the choices they make in everyday living.  Also assisting them to reflect on the reasons they have made those particular choices, the images in this deck are rich, unique, and profound. I know that the deeper insight a person can experience that the Tarot gives us is instrumental. By providing a happier, more focused and spiritual life. It is my belief that by using the Tarot as a tool it allows us to not only reflect on our choices in life that we've made in the past but also how we can make better choices in the now and the future. 

Every day more people ask me “When is your deck coming out?” and “Please let me know when I can buy a deck!”  Well, my friends, now is your chance to help me get this project truly off the ground and running! 


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word!  Even if you cant spare the donation for a deck, a dollar goes a long way and just letting people know what were trying to do here is so appreciated!  Tweet, post to Facebook, your Wordpress blog or any other media you have access to!  Any and all help is appreciated more than I can say on this screen.  Thank you for encouraging and supporting me

story:
The Story

I invite you on a journey filled with new possibilities for MEDUSA and her myth. It’s a journey where MEDUSA STEPS OUT from behind her shadows. Six years ago I began building DIG: An Imagined Archeo-logism, a vast, evolving sculptural installation that addresses the myths of men, women, war, marriage, family, ecology, death and dying. DIG has been mounted in two exhibitions (Xiem Gallery and Kellogg Gallery). MEDUSA STEPS OUT is the third act of DIG and, while I have been working on this project for 6 years, this is the first time I’m asking for support.

Please take a minute now to watch my video and become familiar with the project. I want to excavate Medusa and I want you to become fellow archeologists with me. Together we will uncover her secret and not so secret incarnations. Who she was and is historically and who she is today. I want you to go on this journey with me and I need your help. I need the funds to mount the project. I need this video sent to your people all over the world. I need you to talk about it to galleries and other venues where you may have an ear. Go on this DIG with me. Make a gift. It will help to ensure the successful mounting of MEDUSA STEPS OUT, the final act of this work. Every dollar is fully tax deductible.


What Is Needed & Contributors Acknowledgement:


All contributors will be acknowledged in the catalogue.

storage for 1 year                                                      900.00


TOTAL:                                                                30,000.00


              

Other Ways You Can Help

Want to contribute but don't have the funds right now? You're contribution can be great if you would share this video with your friends and followers on Facebook, Myspace, Twitter, etc. And, remember, never underestimate the power of a dollar! One dollar or 5 dollars can make a huge difference when enough people contribute.

story:
We need your help to revitalize Toronto's holography scene and make Toronto's Nuit Blanche exciting again.

We are a group of undergraduate and graduate students from UofT that founded the officially recognized student group "the Parallax and Interference Guild" in order to promote our shared interest in the art of holography both on and off campus.  Our goal is to organize and curate an exhibit of student made holograms that will also feature some professionally done pieces as well as poetry inspired by our experience as students of holography and original music.

We have secured a space for Toronto's upcoming Nuit Blanche on October 4th in the Trinity College Chapel: with your help we hope to put on a professional quality exhibit  and then move a more modest version of the one night show to a gallery space off campus for several weeks afterwards. Our longterm goal is to make our exhibit an annual fixture that art lovers in the city can look forward to for years to come.


Questions you might have:
What IS a hologram? 
In normal light a hologram will just look like a plate of glass, but when properly illuminated a spectacular image is visible that changes depending on which way the viewer looks at it, in exactly the same way as it would in real life. The image is the result of the pattern made by the interference of two beams of laser light, that is recorded by the photographic emulsion on the surface of the plate. The effect of making the image appear three dimensional (or having full "parallax") is what sets holography apart from other visual mediums like photography.


Will we feature "Princess Leia" style holograms like the Tupac hologram that performed at the Coachella music festival?
Visualizations like that of the Tupac performance aren't actually holograms at all, but merely projections onto a sheet of special plastic called mylar. Pieces like this should be more appropriately referred to as "stereoscopic projections" and, unfortunately, the technology does not yet exist to create holograms such as the ones found in the Star Wars movies. Should we raise enough money, however, we will indeed do our best to include a stereoscopic projection in the Nuit Blanche exhibit.


Why are you so interested in Holography?
Holography occupies a small niche of the art world as it is much less widely practiced than other visual mediums like photography or painting. This in itself motivates us to want to promote it within our community so that we can share with others the amazement we felt the first time we experienced a full parallax hologram.  As Japanese Holographer Setsuko Iishi, affectionately nicknamed as the "magician of light", said: "Light by definition is something that cannot be bent, nor shaped, nor even held. Yet in holography light can be molded like clay, or woven like thread." We are fascinated by the possibilities found in holography as it is an intersection of art and science, proof of which can be found in the classroom of UofT's Holography course (that a number of our members were lucky enough to take this past year with Professor Emanuel Istrate and OCAD's Michael Page) as it brings together students from a wide variety of disciplines.


What will the money we raise be used for?
 We have set our fundraising goal at $30,000 so that we can create an experience for Toronto's Nuit Blanche goers that will get them excited about Holography and generate enough interest to make it worthwhile to move the exhibit to an off campus art gallery afterwards so that we can fulfill our club's goal of promoting this unique art form as much as possible within our community. 
All the money we fundraise will go towards:
-creating the appropriate infrastructure to display a large number of holograms (including display cases, appropriate lights, light rigging, plinths, mounts, projectors, fabric, sound equipment, etc.) 
-creating a stereoscopic projection
-rental of an off campus professional art gallery space
-promoting our event
-printing and displaying the accompanying poetry
-producing and performing the accompanying music


Who are the members of the Parallax and Interference Guild?
Matthew Griffith- MA candidate with the Department of Italian Studies, Treasurer of UofT's only student filmmaking club Raindance on Campus.
Suzanne Marchelewicz- Recent graduate of Architecture and Art History. Current student at SCI-Arc in LA.
Alexander Kershaw- Fourth year Architecture and Visual Studies Student.
Valerie Marshall- Third year Architecture and Art History Student.
Kevin Henriques- Recent graduate of Architecture.
Jordan Policicchio- Current Business Marketing student at George Brown College.
Amr Dodin-
Are we ready for the challenges involved?
While organizing such an event isn't easy, we fully believe we are ready to meet the challenge of producing a professional quality exhibit. Over the past several years members of our group have built an interactive installation that featured at the Art Access charity event at Daniel's Spectrum and the Avenue Road Art School 25th anniversary event at the Toronto Reference Library, helped design and build an installation at the 401 Richmond Bloc Party and organized seminars as part of the Hart House Arts Committee. Members of our group also edited the 2014 edition of the annual Architecture and Visual Studies publication "Shift".
If I can't donate, what else can I do to help?
Even if you can't support us financially, you can help us by spreading the word about our upcoming exhibit and most importantly by coming out yourself to Trinity College Chapel this October 4th!

story:
Summary

We are a French association named „Les Ethiopiques 65“, that is working on a solar panel project to bring constant electricity to Djilor Djidiack, a small village in Senegal.

Djilor Djidiack suffers from different problems. There are two to three power breakdowns weekly, a problem which can be solved by the installation of solar panels. The price for one kilo-watt hour in Senegal is around 22 cents. Compared to France, where the people earn more money, it is really expensive. In France the price for one kilo-watt hour is 14.7 cents.


One of the main problems is the high death rate amongst babies, because there are no incubators to keep the prematurely born children warm. This is why we want to buy incubators to save baby’s lives.

Students are not able to learn and repeat lessons  when it is dark outside and teachers are not able to prepare their lessons for the next day in the evening.

Therefore the association wants to install solar panels on the roof of the kindergarten, the primary school and the hospital to enable the villagers a better life. Thus the high death rate of prematurely born children will decrease and a power breakdown will not have any influence to the death rate anymore.

We are dependent on donations to realize our Solar Africa project. With your help we can improve the health and education conditions in Djilor Djidiack. 

Every single donation is much appreciated!
story_txt:
Summary
We are a French association named „Les Ethiopiques 65“, that is working on a solar panel project  to bring constant electricity to Djilor Djidiack, a small village in Senegal. 
Djilor Djidiack suffers from different problems. There are two 
to three power breakdowns weekly, a problem which can be solved by the 
installation of solar panels. The price for one kilo-watt hour in 
Senegal is around 22 cents. Compared to France, where the people earn 
more money, it is really expensive.  In France the price for one 
kilo-watt hour is 14.7 cents.
 One of the main problems is the 
high death rate amongst babies, because there are no incubators to keep 
the prematurely born children warm. This is why we want to buy 
incubators to save baby’s lives.   Students are not able to learn and 
repeat lessons  when it is dark 
outside and teachers are not able to prepare their lessons for the next 
day in the evening.  Therefore the association wants to 
install solar panels on the roof of the kindergarten, the primary school and the hospital to enable the villagers a better life. Thus the high death rate
 of prematurely born children will decrease and a power breakdown will 
not have any influence to the death rate anymore.  We are 
dependent on donations to realize our Solar Africa project. With your 
help we can improve the health and education conditions in Djilor 
Djidiack. 
Every single donation is much appreciated!

story:
Short Summary

As young and upcoming artists, Alessandra DeLaCruz and Kennedy Yanko have been carving out their niche in the art world from Brooklyn, NY, and are ready to take the next giant leap in their careers by showing with Select Art Fair for Art Basel Miami 2012.  With 260 leading galleries participating and over 50,000 people in attendance for 2011, Art Basel Miami is one of the most highly exposed art fairs in North America. Their Basel or Bust campaign will allow both artists to exhibit their work to a much wider audience on a scale they've never been able to reach alone; exposing them to galleries, curators, collectors and other artists to draw inspiration from and launch their careers into the stratosphere.

Artist Bios

Kennedy Yanko is an American artist born in St.Louis, Missouri. She began showing her work publicly at the age of 15. While studying at the San Francisco Art Institute, Kennedy was introduced to New Genres Art and her work began to evolve into multi-media abstract expression, expanding her talents to include photography, collage, installation, sculpture, and live performance. She has exhibited her work in numerous venues including a solo show in 2008, participated in Social practice art with Creative Times, and has undertaken 2 residencies; 4 years with the famous Living Theater (NYC) and with Master artist Rick Lowe (founder of Project Row house, Board member of The Andy Warhol Foundation) at Atlantic Center for the Arts. Kennedy currently lives in New York City.

Alessandra DeLaCruz is a New York based abstract artist who focuses on process oil painting. Growing up in upstate New York, the textures of her natural surroundings heavily influence Alessandra's work. Painting since she can remember and always resourceful, DeLaCruz started trekking her 7 foot long paintings to Union Square in 2007 to start gaining a wider audience. Graduating with a Bachelors of Fine Arts from FIT in 2009, DeLaCruz has been featured in group exhibitions throughout New York, has held two solo shows, completed several private commissioned works, and has taken to the curatorial field as the Director of Exhibitions at Harmony Gallery in Stony Brook, NY, while working under Independent Curator Ombretta Agro Andruff. She is also the Principal Curator for The East African Center, a non-profit she volunteered with as an art teacher in Kenya in 2011.

Fundraising Breakdown & Contributor Gifts

•   Exhibition fee: $4,800
•   Packing Material for sold artwork in Miami: $500
•   Materials & Postage for campaign gifts: $400
•   IndieGoGo fee: $400-500

Our $6,000 budget doesn't cover airfare, lodging, food or sunscreen. In true starving artist form, these things typically come later in terms of prioritizing when making our artwork.

For your kind patronage to the arts, you will receive a wide range of unique gifts made by US, the artists, in order to show our deep appreciation for your support. From a small square cut out of a larger handmade drawing, to beautiful hand painted coasters, to custom painted clothing or a commissioned piece, a touch of abstract art will find its way into your life for contributing to our cause.

The Impact

We will use every cent of our Basel or Bust campaign money diligently in order to get ourselves to Art Basel this December. Your contributions mean taking both of our careers to the next level, and we couldn't do it without your help!


So many artists are trying to reach out, be exposed, be seen. We are amongst them, emerging artists who have both seized opportunities and created them for ourselves. The fast paced world of art has taught us both great patience and dedication, and we're ready to prove it to the world. From creating live performance pieces to volunteering, we know what it takes to be a hard working artist and are committed to our work. Thank you for your support!

Contributors Thank You

To thank you, on an evening in mid-November, we and the fine folks at Culture Fix Bar & Gallery on the Lower East Side will hold a Contributors Party where NYC based donors will be able to pick up or make arrangements for their gifts, mingle with the artists, friends, and enjoy drink specials after work.

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you thank you thank you for making it THIS far! Other ways you can show your support for us are graciously appreciated:

    •    Please spread the word about our campaign, post it to your facebook, twitter,  etc., make some noise and we're bound to be on our way! You can use the Indiegogo share tools for this :)

    •    See us on the street? Give us a pat on the back for support, or a hug!


Love and Gratitude,
Alessandra and Kennedy
AKA
YankoCruz

Love and Gratitude,Alessandra and KennedyAKAYankoCruz

story:
SoftBox Photography Collective, is a self-sufficient student-led platform ran by final year photography students studying at The Edinburgh College of Art. Softbox is in its second successful year and will be independently exhibiting work just off London's Brick Lane at The Rag Factory from the 24th to the 29th of July.

Throughout the past year we have already raised  funds with our successful ECA exhibition club nights but we need your help to get our art on the wall. Transporting our work, funding the gallery space and creating promotional material are all costs we need to consider and we are seeking your generous sponsorship to help us meet these goals. 

With the funding you provide we also aim to produce a limited run of handmade zine showcasing the work of our members and sponsor's generosity. This will be launched at the exhibition and distributed at independent book shops and zine-fairs throughout Scotland and England. 



About softbox

The role of the collective varies from exhibiting as a group to instigating collaborative pieces and providing financial assistance to our members. Through this we aim to create a unique opportunity in which our members can gain valuable experience outside of an academic setting; networking, publicizing their work and inspiring others.


Last years graduate members successfully crowd sourced funding to take their work to London and exhibited at the Freerange Art and Design Festival.



Having already secured The Rag Factory and set up initial marketing your generous support will go onto fund the final remaining areas;

  • Transport, £200
  • Setup costs, £100
  • Limited run of handmade zines, £175
  • Promotional materials, £250
  • Marketing and Advertising, £375

story:
The Fresh Fruit Squad is proud to announce the Loosely Curated Show, a two day exhibition presenting twenty up-and-coming artists in Los Angeles. 

   The range is vast. Some are wild, full of marks and color. Some are quiet, contemplative, and sincere. Some are direct and playful. Some are precise and engineered. Some are dark and strange. Some are full of emotion, soul, and humanity. Some ooze style and positive vibes. Some are experimental and instinctual. Some has narrative, culture, and history. Underneath it all lies a hidden energy: friendship. 
    Like at a potluck dinner, each artist brings their favorite dish to share. There’s bound to be something that will make your mind salivate, so please join us for our debut show! 

We believe that art is meant to been seen. You can't wait for the art world to take notice. Putting on this show is a manifestation of those feelings. We are creating fresh and exciting work that we'd like to share with everyone.


Artists involved.

Addison Eaton, AJ Dungo, Alejandra Fernandez, Aryo Toh Djojo, Billy Frolov, Bryan Sang Park, Cassie Zhang, Chris Youssef, Eddie Bong, Edward Cushenberry, Hertz Alegrio, Jacob Lenc, Jonathan Kvassay, Lacy Yang, Lily Liyi Chen, Maxwell McMaster, Sally Deng, Tom Eichaker, Zach Mendoza, Zander Bice 

Show your support-

  By donating to this campaign you will help us off set the costs of the show. The 3 day rental of the venue cost us $1015. The additional $185 will cover Indiegogo fee's as well as refreshments for the opening. We are asking that you give whatever amount you can to support the show as well as this fresh and exciting art community in LA. In return we have some great gifts to offer you!

  We've made loose collections of work in the form of packages! They will be filled with Zines, stickers, postcards, handmade prints, digital prints, original drawings, stickers, pins, and maybe more!


Here is an example of some of the things the packages may contain.

Zines available from-
Addison Eaton, AJ Dungo, Alejandra Fernandez, Billy Frolov, Bryan Park Sang, Cassie Zhang, Lacy Yang, & Tom Eichacker.
Pins from-
Alejandra Fernandez and Addison Eaton
Stickers from-
Addison Eaton and Lacy Yang
Prints available from-
Alejandra fernandez, Bryan Sang Park, Eddie Bong, Hertz Alegro, Jonathan Kvassay, Lacy Yang, Lily Liyi Chen, Maxwell Mcmaster, Sally Deng, Zach Mendoza, and Zander Bice.
Original works available from-
Addison Eaton, Aryo Toh Djojo, Cassie Zhang, Chris Youssef, Edward Cushenberry, Jacob Lenc, and Zach Mendoza. (Possibly more as well)

The Impact-

   By supporting this show you aren't just supporting us as artists, you are supporting the young artists of today who create the art world of tomorrow. We want to share our ways of looking at the world. We want to instill excitement and a passion for art in everyday life. We are coming together in this space to interact with the greater LA community, to have conversations about and celebrations for art.
   This is our first show as a collective. Many of us have been previously been in group shows, made artist books, had features on websites, sold work to collectors, had interviews, and built credibility behind our work. The most important part of what we do is the fact that we are productive and hungry artists.

Risks-

   There aren't too many risks going into this project. We've already booked a space, have a collection of works, and have plans for how we will delegate duties between us.
   Since our opening will take place once the LA Art Book Fair closes at 6pm (just one block away) there is some concern that our show will become an after party. This means that there's a very serious risk that we might need to make an extra beer run!
 If necessary, we will cover the costs ourselves by finding another way to raise funds. Crowdfunding is our best and favorite option because it's an easy way for us to give to the people who give to us. We are a group that is fresh out of school or soon-to-be, so any financial support is greatly appreciated.

   Starting this campaign was in hopes that the people who surround us would help support all the wonderful things we are making. Because between school tuition, rent, art supplies, pet food, and everything else it's probably not the most logical idea to take this on. But remember, the world needs dreamers!
  

Cheerleaders-

   If this campaign really strikes a chord with you or maybe you're in love with one of us, please share far and wide! 
   Social media helps but making plans and bringing friends to our show means a lot more. Hope to see you there!!


*Graphics designed by Eddie Bong.

story:
Texte en français un peu plus bas

Yes, we reached our goal. Thank you, but we still need your help to reach our stretch goal!

Salut, we are Midnight Poutine, a Burning Man camp from Québec :)  We've been feeding hungry burners the best poutine west of Montréal since 2009!
 

What's poutine, you ask?  It's a Québecois tradition of french fries smothered with cheese curds and topped with hot gravy!   YUM!! 

Last year, 2000 hungry burners got a taste of Midnight Poutine.   It's a party every night with Québecois music, burn barrels, sexy people,  line-ups around the block and, of course, poutine! 

We don't want to leave anybody hungry :)  Please help us feed more burners in 2014 by funding the best late-night party food camp on the playa!! 

Your Contributions Fund

  • Cheese Curds    Hell yeah, we use real cheese curds!  No effin grated cheese at our camp!  And it turns out that cheese curds are our biggest expense!!!
  •  The Other Ingredients  Potatoes, gravy,  and oil.  It costs about $2500 to make 2000 poutines.  And there's propane and other things too..
  •  Grosse Poutine  How will you find us?  Follow our giant LED cup of yellow fries lighting up the playa sky. 
  • Unsexy Logistics  It takes a lot to set up a food camp, make eating areas and decorations, not to mention getting all this stuff to Burning Man from Montreal.   'nuff said.  We promise that ALL the money you contribute goes toward running the poutine kitchen!

Our target is $2000, so please help us get there!! 

Our stretch goal is $2500 to afford electric refrigeration and power!   For years, we've been lo-tech and spent a lot of time going to Arctica every day to haul back ice for our cheese coolers....  but we can always dream...

If you contribute, we offer you our dustiest heartfelt appreciation as well as Midnight Poutine stickers, pins, postcard and forks because we love you! See you at home   <3 <3 <3 !!!!!! 


Français :

Nous sommes Midnight Poutine, un campement à Burning Man majoritairement de Montréal, Québec. Notre nom définit notre objectif: servir de la poutine aux « Burners » affamés chaque soir à minuit. Mais la poutine c’est quoi?  La poutine est un plat traditionnel québécois, un délice bien gras. Pour être plus précis, il s’agit de frites parsemées de fromage en grains et le tout couvert d’une sauce brune BBQ bien chaude. Ça ne titille pas vos papilles?  Détrompez-vous : il s’agit en fait de la meilleure chose que vous aurez engloutit sur la playa.

En 2013  nous avons servi approximativement plus de 2000 poutines.  Nous visons ce nombre encore cette année, tout en rendant la visite au camp une expérience encore plus intéressante !  Mais les coûts reliés à tout ceci sont importants et impossible à compenser avec  seulement les frais de camps que nous payons personnellement. Voilà pourquoi nous avons besoin de votre aide.

Vous pouvez faire un don si vos souvenirs de dégustation de poutines stimulent votre générosité ou simplement si vous croyez en l’idée de propager les idées gastronomiques québécoises à tous nos Burners affamés.


Dans les dernières années, nous avons dû arrêter les files d’attentes qui s’étendaient souvent tout autour du campement.  Nous ne voulons pas laisser personne le ventre vide! Voici ce dont nous avons besoin : 

Plus d’ingrédients:

  • Le fromage en grain est notre plus grand dépense mais il y a aussi les patates, la sauce, l’huile de friture, le gaz propane ainsi que toutes les assiettes de papier et fourchettes de bois utilisées pour le service. 
  • Notre budget d’ingrédients l'an passé  était d’environ  2500$.  

Un plus beau camp

  • Le projet jouit maintenant d'une superbe réputation et popularité, nous voulons maintenant amener le projet à un niveau de maturité supérieur . Les gens attendent parfois près de deux heure pour leur poutine. Nous voulons rendre l'expérience de visiter Midnight Poutine encore plus intéressante. Nous voulons améliorer le look général du camp, ajouter de l'éclairage plus joli.
  • Notre emblème "Grosse Poutine" ce contenant de patates frites géant qui trône à plus de 20' dans les airs, a eu la vie difficile ces dernières années. Nous voulons en faire une toute nouvelle version avec avec de belles frites géantes en 3D le tout illuminé avec de puissantes lumières LED. 

Grace à votre contribution, nous pourrons viser grand et nourrir d’avantage de Burners affamés cette année !  La playa de burning man a besoin d’avantage de plats réconfortants de fin de soirée!

Notre objectif est de 2000 $ car en combinant nos frais de camps personnels et d’autres moyens de financement, nous serons capables de combler l’augmentation des frais pour  les ingrédients et le transport des marchandises. Si nous dépassons cet objectif et atteignons 2500$, nous serons en mesure d’acquérir un réfrigérateur électrique et la génératrice électrique pour conserver notre fromage à une température parfaite. Dans le passé la gestion de la glace et des glacières pour la conservation du fromage s'est avéré tout un défi.  Soyez assurés que l’argent recueilli servira uniquement à combler les dépenses de Midnight Poutine.

En gratitude de votre contribution, nous avons quelques items promotionnels à l’effigie de Midnight Poutine à vous offrir (Autocollants, macarons, carte postale personnalisé et même des fourchettes à effigie de Midnight Poutine )

Notre nom définit notre objectif: servir de la poutine aux « Burners » affamés chaque soir à minuit. Mais la poutine c’est quoi?  La poutine est un plat traditionnel québécois, un délice bien gras. Pour être plus précis, il s’agit de frites parsemées de fromage en grains et le tout couvert d’une sauce brune BBQ bien chaude. Ça ne titille pas vos papilles?  Détrompez-vous : il s’agit en fait de la meilleure chose que vous aurez engloutit sur la playa.En 2013  nous avons servi approximativement plus de 2000 poutines.  Nous visons ce nombre encore cette année, tout en rendant la visite au camp une expérience encore plus intéressante !  Mais les coûts reliés à tout ceci sont importants et impossible à compenser avec  seulement les frais de camps que nous payons personnellement. Voilà pourquoi nous avons besoin de votre aide.Vous pouvez faire un don si vos souvenirs de dégustation de poutines stimulent votre générosité ou simplement si vous croyez en l’idée de propager les idées gastronomiques québécoises à tous nos Burners affamés.Dans les dernières années, nous avons dû arrêter les files d’attentes qui s’étendaient souvent tout autour du campement.  Nous ne voulons pas laisser personne le ventre vide! Voici ce dont nous avons besoin : Plus d’ingrédients:
Le fromage en grain est notre plus grand dépense mais il y a aussi les patates, la sauce, l’huile de friture, le gaz propane ainsi que toutes les assiettes de papier et fourchettes de bois utilisées pour le service. 
Notre budget d’ingrédients l'an passé  était d’environ  2500$.  
Un plus beau camp
Le projet jouit maintenant d'une superbe réputation et popularité, nous voulons maintenant amener le projet à un niveau de maturité supérieur . Les gens attendent parfois près de deux heure pour leur poutine. Nous voulons rendre l'expérience de visiter Midnight Poutine encore plus intéressante. Nous voulons améliorer le look général du camp, ajouter de l'éclairage plus joli.
Notre emblème "Grosse Poutine" ce contenant de patates frites géant qui trône à plus de 20' dans les airs, a eu la vie difficile ces dernières années. Nous voulons en faire une toute nouvelle version avec avec de belles frites géantes en 3D le tout illuminé avec de puissantes lumières LED. 
Grace à votre contribution, nous pourrons viser grand et nourrir d’avantage de Burners affamés cette année !  La playa de burning man a besoin d’avantage de plats réconfortants de fin de soirée!Notre objectif est de 2000 $ car en combinant nos frais de camps personnels et d’autres moyens de financement, nous serons capables de combler l’augmentation des frais pour  les ingrédients et le transport des marchandises. Si nous dépassons cet objectif et atteignons 2500$, nous serons en mesure d’acquérir un réfrigérateur électrique et la génératrice électrique pour conserver notre fromage à une température parfaite. Dans le passé la gestion de la glace et des glacières pour la conservation du fromage s'est avéré tout un défi.  Soyez assurés que l’argent recueilli servira uniquement à combler les dépenses de Midnight Poutine.En gratitude de votre contribution, nous avons quelques items promotionnels à l’effigie de Midnight Poutine à vous offrir (Autocollants, macarons, carte postale personnalisé et même des fourchettes à effigie de Midnight Poutine )

story:
Project Summary...

TraceLaboratory was founded by G. Louise Cooper and Sarah Yasdani, who met while collaborating on a project in Paris. Cooper is performance and multi-media artist and native of suburban Detroit, who received her BA in Theatre Performance from Oakland University. Sarah Yasdani is a conceptual artist from Stockholm, Sweden, who has exhibited work in Stockholm, Paris and Reykjavik.

While in Paris, we conceived the idea of the MM Art Biome. We thought, what if we take an empty space, a single idea, and a group of artists who have never worked together, and built a thematic micro-culture?

The MM Art Biome will be a three-day pop-up exhibition that will be based around a single theme (Micro/Macro) and color motif (indigo). Anywhere from 15-20 artists will be invited to join us in exploring these ideas, creating works based upon them, and in building a temporary sanctuary and festival for them .

The works exhibited can range from installation to opera, without limit.

Rather than creating a simple, themed gallery, we seek to create an experience for both artist and viewer. We seek to create a "biome" in which we are all united under a single concept. A space where we can live intermingled with art. A space dedicated equally to artist and viewer, where creation can continue without limit and that line may begin to blur.

Where donations will go...

Just as any major event, this will require some funding behind it. Here is a run-down on where our money will be going...
- Rental of the space
- Utilities
- Technical materials (Lighting, Projectors, Sound, etc.)
- Liability Insurance
- Concessions
- We would love love love to help our artists pay for their materials/ the shipment of their work

The Impact...

Your donation will go towards something much needed in our modern life. This project is an act of freedom and an act of community. The important thing is being able to create something out of nothing, and to do it together. To realize the variations that exist upon one single concept, the different perceptions individuals inherently have. To realize that it is still possible to come together, to connect on a basic level. Undistracted, open.

And we do not simply want you to donate- we want you to come experience it yourself.

How you can take part...

First and foremost, even the smallest donation will help us on our way.

However, if it's just not possible to donate, you can still help!
- First, share our campaign via social media or the old-fashioned word-of-mouth with everyone you know.
- Second, not only are we looking for donations, but also submissions from artists who would like to be involved in the event. (Find submission information on our website)
- Third, if you have any technical equipment on-hand (i.e. lighting fixtures, projectors, stereos, space heaters...) and would be willing to lend it to us, we would be eternally thankful.
- And lastly, come to the event in October!

story:
What's the Rabbit Hole, anyway?

The Rabbit Hole started as a place for student artists to interact with each other and share their work in a welcoming, off-campus space. Over the past two years the community has grown and grown and we couldn't be more thrilled. Poets, actors, stand up comedians, spoken word artists, storytellers, literary readers, academics, essayists - students, recent grads, more established artists - everyone is welcome at our open mic. Our features also represent this diversity. We are passionate about the interplay between artists, and about providing space for underrepresented voices.

We are asking for $1000 to run this season, our third. While we were students we were able to get some funding from our student society, but now that we have graduated we are seeking alternate sources. Grants take time, and we won't see money until we're starting our fourth season. We are passionate about this series and so are currently funding it ourselves, on our recent grad budgets.

The Rabbit Hole pays its featured performers, which is something we believe strongly in. We'd like to give better honorariums and offer travel grants to visiting features. On top of those costs, we also have fees related to our website. 

Who are we?

The Rabbit Hole is run by three young women with a range of identities and backgrounds. Currently, we're paying for the series out of pocket - it's that important to us! 

Our passion is getting people together to experience a range of art forms, and elevating voices of people who might not otherwise be heard because of their content or style, because of their lack of quantitative experience, or because of the identities they hold. Most of our features are at really early stages in their career. We feature a lot of queer content and radical theory. As intersectional feminists, we believe that representation is powerful and necessary. As white cis women, we know that providing a platform for artists to speak for themselves is a potent vehicle for progress.

Each of us hold a degree from UVic in writing, professional writing, and/or English, as well as other majors and minors. We are poets, fiction writers, and theatre artists. We volunteer our time (a lot of our time!) because we believe that artists deserve a space to meet each other, hear each other, and learn from each other - whether on stage or in the crowd. For more about us individually, please check out the bios on our website.

What's the money for?

We are privileged to have the Copper Owl give us their space each month, so we are not asking for money to assist in venue rental.

We currently pay our features $20 for a twenty minute performance. Over a season (September - April, plus a summer special), we spend about $500 on honorariums. We'd like to increase this. 

For performances that had multiple authors, or multiple people on stage, we'd like to increase the honorarium accordingly. We'd also like to be able to invite one or two more established features per season and to pay them more professional rates. We estimate we'll need $200 to cover these extra costs.

So that we can continue to expand the scope of the series, we'd like to have a travel fund. To cover the costs of two out-of-town readers per season, we need $200 (round-trip ferry tickets with a vehicle, or walk on tickets plus part of hotel costs, etc). 

Our webhosting and domain costs are over $100 a year. We did a lot of research, and this is the lowest price we can find for the services and features we need.

Anything else we have, we'd like to put into marketing. Posters on campuses and in the community would be great, plus paying into ads on our social media platforms. Our goal is always to increase attendance and grow the community.

Why though?

Artists are often expected to do their job for free. But art, music, writing, performance - all of these take time, training, and talent. We believe firmly that artists should be paid for their work just like any other professional. 

For young and emerging artists, pay is scarce and costs are high. Being able to pay our performers and readers is so meaningful for us, because we know what's gone into the pieces. A paid gig is a stepping stone for those early in their careers.

But we also want to expand what we're currently giving. We'd like to offer better honorariums, especially for more established artists, performers that have travelled from outside of Victoria to be with us, and collaborators (such as if a playwright has actors join them on stage, or if a piece has more than one author).

Beyond paying our amazing features as close to what they deserve as we can afford, we also want to provide more content for our audience. Interviews, podcasts, recordings of featured performances, and print material are all future projects we'd like to start now, with your help.

What do you get out of this?

Other than a vibrant, welcoming, thriving community of artists? Other than a space in which to hear the work young people are doing? Other than an opportunity to try out your own work in a safe, casual, semi-professional environment? Other than a few hours every month to participate completely in artistic pursuits?

Well, we do have perks for donations: sweet Rabbit Hole swag, tickets to an exciting party in December, eternal glory, and our gratitude.

Importantly, we are offering our services as experienced editors to help you polish up your own work. We have training in editing poetry, fiction, creative non-fiction, journalism, marketing copy, stage-play, screenplay, and academic writing. If you select a perk that includes the option for editing, your work will be assigned to the person with the most experience in your genre who is best suited to your needs. We'll also have some members of our Rabbit Hole community - also trained in editing and writing - available to help us out and to give you the best possible feedback.

How else can you help?

We know that many people in our community won't be able to contribute financially - as artists and recent grads ourselves, we understand. But you can still get involved in the campaign!

Please share our campaign and let others know we're fundraising. 

Follow us on our social medias and help us spread the word on those platforms - retweets, likes, and shout-outs all help us grow our audience. Sharing the Facebook events each month makes a big difference to our attendance.

Attending our events is what means most to us. Braving the open mic is good for us, for you, and for everybody exposed to your work and courage. 

Thank you for being a part of this community, contributing to it with your vibrance, talent, and passion.

story:
Montana's "Glacier" Museum

The Hockaday Museum of Art was founded in 1968 as a local art center and has grown into the regional cultural center it is today.  The mission of the Museum is "to enrich the cultural life of our community and region, and preserve the artistic legacy of Montana and Glacier National Park."  Many school, group and Senior tours introduce people of all ages to Art, and outreach programs take learning directly to area schools.

Visitors with physical limitations must be able to use the Museum's only elevator to access either of the main floors because the wheelchair-accessible entrance is on a "mezzanine" level due to the construction of the historic Carnegie Library building in which it is located.  

The failure of the elevator means that Persons With Disabilities may not be able to see all of the exhibits, attend functions or visit the Museum at all.  The elevator must be repaired as soon as possible.

The Museum holds several major fundraising events throughout the year, but has experienced a decline in overall revenue.  At this time, the Museum lacks the availability of immediate funds to cover the entire cost of the elevator repair.    

Emergency Elevator Repair

On August 21, 2013, the Hockaday's only elevator stopped functioning with an 80 year old woman trapped inside.  Following rescue efforts, the elevator's hydraulic system and electrical components completely failed. 

  • An estimate of $10,000 has been given to repair the elevator's hydraulic system, with an additional $5,000 estimated to fix the supporting electrical system and components, for a total of $15,000 required
  • The Museum is attempting to find emergency grants to cover the repair costs, but the amounts fall short of what is needed
  • The Museum will have to take out a loan to cover any additional costs that fall short of fundraising efforts

The Impact

Your contribution will help the Museum repair the elevator much more quickly, restoring access to Persons With Disabilities.  

  • Monthly "Senior Tea & Tour Days" offer free admission to Seniors age 60+, who come to enjoy a day out from their independent and assisted living homes
  • Frequent school tours may include individuals with various special needs

Other Ways You Can Help

The Hockaday appreciates your time in reading this plea for help.  If you are able to contribute, you have the Museum's gratitude and thanks.  Please spread the word about our efforts and consider using the Indiegogo share tools.

story:
You can make a direct impact on the new season's programming of THE CRANKY SHOW, with your hosts Doctor Cranky and EYEGORE, at DOCTOR CRANKY'S LAB-RAT-ORY.

Creating new content is of the utmost importance to the Lab-RAT-ory crew. THE CRANKY SHOW is a hands-on hobby/art/how-to/educational vlog about art, scale models and miniatures. It serves a large audience of model builders, dioramists, and hobby/craft enthusiasts.

Your generous contribution will go a long way in providing us much needed support to maintain the vlog and continue to produce new content for the show. Every little bit helps and is greatly appreciated, but if you donate at a certain level, we would love to send you some thank you gifts direct from the Lab-RAT-ory.

For donations of at least $25 dollars, you will receive a Lab-RAT-ory T-shirt featuring one of our original Lab-RAT-ory designs.

For donations of at least $100, you will be automatically enrolled in CRANKY'S CLUBHOUSE, which entitles you to receive a variety of swag, books, and products direct from Doctor Cranky's Lab-RAT-ory.

For donations of $1000 dollars or more, you will receive an original piece of artwork by Doctor Cranky, and a model from Doctor Cranky's collection, built by Doctor Cranky himself!.

We are a dedicated but small crew here at the Lab-RAT-ory, so your generosity will go a long way. We look forward to the new season of THE CRANKY SHOW, and with your support it will be the best season yet!

 

THANK YOU!

Doctor Cranky & EYEGORE

story:
This is an event about love
Made with devotion
For the friend who gives everything
Though we expect nothing

There is no ‘I’ or ‘you’ in this play
Only music, poetry and dance
Thousands of years of wisdom
A moment of happenstance

Life is but a breath
This night contains a lifetime
Join us in this revelry
Fill your cup with our wine

PLEASE HELP US GROW OUR CAST NUMBERS

Neworld Theatre and the Vancouver branch of the Nimatullahi Sufi order have joined together to create a unique event which attempts to capture the spirit of love and unity through a story steeped in tradition yet expressed through a modern artistic fusion of styles. 

The vision for this event is to have a large cast of actors, musicians, dancers, poets and community participants.  With your donation to the project you are helping realize the full potential of what will prove to be an unforgettable evening.

 ABOUT THE CREATIVE TEAM

Camyar Chai (Writer/Co-Director)

Camyar is blessed to be back with his friends at Neworld.  He has come back to the theatre inspired to create a devotional piece, which for him is best embodied in Krisna Das’ message to his spiritual teacher:

My Gurudev I offer these flowers of my faith at your feet
Whatever I have, you have given to me, and I dedicate it all to you.
I have no love, nor do I know you.
I don’t even have the strength to worship you,
But this mind of mine, this body of mine,
my every atom_ is dedicated to you.
You are the only one in my heart and my thoughts.
You are the one who I call out to.
Now Make me your instrument...all I am I offer to you.

Chelsea Haberlin (Co-Director)

Chelsea is Co-Artistic Producer of ITSAZOO Productions and Associate Artistic Director with Neworld Theatre. She has directed many projects with ITSAZOO ranging from outdoor promenade adaptations of fairy tales to hard-hitting political dramas. Chelsea has directed for a number of companies in Vancouver including Pacific Theatre, Western Gold, Delinquent Theatre and Upintheair Theatre. She has an MFA in directing from UBC and a BFA with a specialization in Applied Theatre from UVic. She is the recipient of the Sydney J Risk award in directing and the Ray Michal award for outstanding body of work by an emerging director.

“Many aspects of the Sufi faith mirror the values my parents instilled in me.  In a certain sense, Doost has affirmed for me that celebrating emotions is a sign of strength, not a weakness. It took me some time to understand the Doost story, but now I realize it’s simply all about love.” –Chelsea Haberlin

Parjad Sharifi (Designer)

Parjad is a theatre scenographer, director and new media creator. Parjad’s research interest is exploring designing techniques of expressive scenography in performing arts and urban design within the context of digital and interactive technologies. His latest essay with the title of “Bioscenography: Towards the Scenography of Affection” has been published along with other essays by international scenographers and performance theorists in print with title of “Presence and Absence: The Performing Body”. He is assistant professor of stage design and technical theatre at the University of The Fraser Valley and a full member of Associated Designers of Canada. Parjad is a Jessie Award winner and a graduate of UBC.

“Doost sparked my interest because Sufism has always been integrated with Persian culture. While I'm not religious, I grew up in the Islamic world and a sense of mysticism has always been in my consciousness. With this play, even the set design is within a Sufi framework: light is used symbolically rather than literally. I'm very drawn to this visual metaphor." –Parjad Sharifi

THE BAND

(Soley) Soleyman Vaseghi was born into a family with many generations of involvement with Sufism. He began his formal musical education by joining the Opera Choir at the Roudaki Opera Hall. He was introduced as "Soley" on National Iranian Radio and Television when he was a student of Sociology at the University of Tehran. He then began composing his own music. He also undertook extensive research in Persian literature, poetry, and different styles of music. Before he left Iran in 1986, he produced several albums in the so called "New Age" style albums for the international audience. This music was inspired by the teachings of Sufism and incorporated the poetry of the great Sufi masters, such as Rumi, Hafez, Roudaki, and Sohrab Sepehri. His albums, Vaghe (The Incident); Ab (The water), and Rangin-Kaman(The Rainbow) are the results of this journey. Soley joined the Lian Ensemble in 2002, initiating his involvement within the Persian Classical music. Doost (Friend) is a manifestation of Truth. When we walk with this friend, we experience love, kindness and respect in this world.

Brandon Walker's creativity has primarily found expression through private reflection and amateur, community-level music projects. From an early age, he played piano, then trumpet, then percussion, winning several awards in jazz and classical performance.  In his early twenties, Brandon dabbled in writing, self-publishing a novella.  He also co-wrote and performed in a short play called The Sailor and the Witch, a reflection on his service as a submariner in Operation Iraqi Freedom while finding a spiritual home with alternative communities in Maui's Kipahulu Valley.  Since moving to Canada in 2004, Brandon has composed, led, and performed with several bands, primarily on trumpet.  He is currently pursuing an original art-rock/synthpop project with his wife and friends.

"Doost began for me the first time I visited the Sufi tavern in Vancouver. The experience of meditating together with a group of devotees gave me a glimpse into a rich tradition where intimacy with the Friend is patiently, intentionally, passionately cultivated, and where the most respected members in the community serve others. I'm truly honoured to be a part of this production. I believe there is a hunger among us to connect to the Divine, and Doost beautifully exemplifies this connection on stage!"

Ali Razmi is a Tar and Setar player as well as a composer. He started to play in a Nimatollahi Khaneghah 22 years ago. 11 years ago he was initiated by his Sufi Master Hazrat Mohheb Ali Shah in Iran.  He believe that Sufism and Music are the best gifts from God to him. 

Hamin Honari plays percussion. He grew up in a musical family where he was exposed to traditional Persian Music at an early age.  His connection to Sufism is mainly through the music that is inspired from Sufism which in turn has inspired him.  

Zion Fyah is the lead singer of I'land. Rhythm Guitar. He is a devoted student of Roots Reggae. 


CAST

Vajieh Tiv

Doost will be Vajieh’s first foray into theatre.

“I first met Master Javad Nurbakhsh while a student of psychology at the University of Tehran where he was a professor of psychiatry. At the time, I was not aware that he was the head of the Sufi Order, but I felt a deep kinship with him. Years later, while visiting a friend involved in the Los Angeles Sufi Order, I spotted his picture on the wall of her friend's home and put it all together. Its an honour for me to connect with the divine. Doost is yet another opportunity to connect with him. The Master was selfless and if I can emulate just a shard of his life, I will be grateful.” –Vanieh Tiv

Sofia Newman

Sofia Bunting Newman is a 19-year-old performer from Vancouver, B.C.and has appeared in several local productions. She participated in Carousel’s Teen Shakespeare Programme from 2008-2014. She has recently been participating in Peter Sklar’s Beginnings Workshop, where she has had the pleasure of singing Off-Broadway at the Sage Theater in New York, and studying under such people as Mikey Brett and Adam Penford in London, England.

“The Doost story is surreal and abstract to me. It’s hard to put your finger on what it’s about, but that’s the magic of it. I was drawn to this production in part because of its exploration of the search for one’s identity. I’ve often wondered what to believe in and this play opened up my own horizons. The Sufi path is intriguing to me because it’s about surrender to a higher power and being in service to others. I’ve never been a part of a play with such a unique purpose.” –Sofia Newman

Richard Newman

Richard Newman has been making theatre for close to half a century.  Born in Chicago, he has a degree from Knox College in Galesburg, Illinois. He trained at The American Conservatory Theater in San Francisco, spent a season with the Oregon Shakespeare Festival, then got his first "professional" union gig: a winter children's theatre tour of the interior of British Columbia.  Though much of his professional life has been spent on stage, screen and in the recording studio, he has been a part of several musical ensembles and had a 3-year stint as the host of an Award-winning weekly Sunday morning TV show for young people on the CBC.

“The Doost project has been incredibly reaffirming for me. At 69, I'm at an age where things are changing so quickly. My daughter has grown up and left home and I am at a new stage of life where I can ask myself: 'what do I want for me now?'  

Somehow, this story spoke to me as I was wrestling with this question. I have come to realize I don’t want to ask 'what if…' anymore. I don’t want to doubt as much. I’ve been looking for a greater sense of comfort and meaning in my life and this play came along at just the right time. I’ve reached a point where I don’t aim for a particular destination, but want to relish a journey instead. I still envy people with faith.” –Richard Newman

Nadeem Umar Khitab

Hailing from Toronto, Nadeem studied acting at Cawthra Park Secondary and Ryerson Theatre School. He performed with The Classical Theatre Project for three years and has been involved in several film and TV projects. Nadeem self-published a book of poetry after a life­ altering stay in California. He currently resides in Vancouver, BC with his playwright fiancée, Sasha Singer­-Wilson.

"When I first read the script for Doost, it was like walking into someone's dream. Though I was raised as a Roman Catholic, I have always been drawn to the more mystical aspects of spirituality.  I don’t 'need to know' if there is an actual God -- I do need to feel my personal connection to the universe. In this play, the character of Javad is a person of few possessions and yet he gives all that he has away. That’s something I deeply admire, yet struggle to emulate myself. If I can surrender more of my ego through this creative process, that will be of lasting significance.” –Nadeem Umar Khitab

Luc Roderique

Luc Roderique originally hails from Ottawa, Ontario but moved west to pursue a career in acting and now calls Vancouver his home. His love for art, words, and expression is rivalled only by his passions for social issues, music, fitness, and the natural world. He has worked on a wide variety of film, TV and theatre projects. Luc is a Jessie Award winner and a graduate of Studio 58.

“I had this instant personal understanding and recognition in my soul when I read this script. Each cast member plays multiple characters, but represents one life force: one energy. That sort of universality of spirit and the simple beauty in the text and poetry really resonated with me and spoke to a place of deeper understanding within me. I was raised as a Buddhist, but have noticed striking similarities between Buddhist and Sufi philosophies and I’ve found myself resonating with Sufism and its sense of oneness. I'm not very religious in the traditional sense, but would definitely consider myself to be a very spiritual person. And that sense of spirituality stems from a deeply held belief that we’re all the same, all one. The sense of love and acceptance amongst this cast and crew is palpable and a somewhat rare experience to come across.”

Maya Lee

Maya graduated with a BA honours in Film from London Metropolitan University. She played principle roles in multiple student films, before going on to study Acting in Film at the Vancouver Film School.  Once back in London Maya set up her own film acting school with esteemed professionals. Maya was known in London for her innovative Film program that brought professional writers, directors and actors together to better understand each other’s profession and pull together, while workshopping and shooting original scripts. She has written, directed and performed in three of her own shorts, a play of hers in London, as well as performed in experimental productions of other directors. Maya has been a private coach in Vancouver since 2007. An advanced Yogini, Maya also teaches yoga and meditation to actors to support their craft. As a singer/songwriter Maya is currently recording her new CD with original music, Maya is a published poet, a lyricist.

"I have been so moved and affirmed by my experience with this production. Through this play, I discovered Sufism to be an extension of my most formative experiences in the unfoldment of life. I've always had a strong desire to connect to essential truth and Sufism took away my sense of being as alone in the world. I have been a person on a path to healing and evolution for some time, and now I have a new language to draw from that goes beyond words and literary understandings to a place where truth is something I can feel. I feel love itself drew me to Doost.”
story_txt:
This is an event about loveMade with devotionFor the friend who gives everythingThough we expect nothingThere is no ‘I’ or ‘you’ in this playOnly music, poetry and danceThousands of years of wisdomA moment of happenstanceLife is but a breathThis night contains a lifetimeJoin us in this revelryFill your cup with our winePLEASE HELP US GROW OUR CAST NUMBERSNeworld Theatre and the Vancouver branch of the Nimatullahi Sufi order have joined together to create a unique event which attempts to capture the spirit of love and unity through a story steeped in tradition yet expressed through a modern artistic fusion of styles. The vision for this event is to have a large cast of actors, musicians, dancers, poets and community participants.  With your donation to the project you are helping realize the full potential of what will prove to be an unforgettable evening. ABOUT THE CREATIVE TEAM

Camyar
Chai (Writer/Co-Director)

Camyar is blessed to be back with his friends at
Neworld.  He has come back to the theatre
inspired to create a devotional piece, which for him is best embodied in Krisna
Das’ message to his spiritual teacher:
My Gurudev I offer these
flowers of my faith at your feet
Whatever I have, you have given to me, and I dedicate
it all to you.
I have no love, nor do I know you.
I don’t even have the strength to worship you,
But this mind of mine, this body of mine,
my every atom_ is dedicated to you.
You are the only one in my heart and my thoughts.
You are the one who I call out to.
Now Make me your instrument...all I am I offer to
you.
Chelsea
Haberlin (Co-Director)
Chelsea is Co-Artistic
Producer of ITSAZOO Productions and Associate Artistic Director with Neworld
Theatre. She has directed many projects with ITSAZOO
ranging from outdoor promenade adaptations of fairy tales to hard-hitting
political dramas. Chelsea has directed for a number of companies in Vancouver
including Pacific Theatre, Western Gold, Delinquent Theatre and Upintheair
Theatre.
She has an MFA in directing from UBC and a BFA with a specialization in
Applied Theatre from UVic. She is the recipient of the Sydney J Risk award in
directing and the Ray Michal award for outstanding body of work by an emerging
director. 
“Many
aspects of the Sufi faith mirror the values my parents instilled in me. 
In a certain sense, Doost has affirmed for me that celebrating emotions is a
sign of strength, not a weakness. It took me some time to understand the Doost
story, but now I realize it’s simply all about love.” –Chelsea Haberlin

story:
Artist Residency Morocco 

Sharing the Story: Desert to Desert

Welcome to my campaign, fellow traveler; I am excited to share the adventure of my very first Artist in Residence. My name is Juliana Coles and I am a mixed media artist creating in the High Desert of Albuquerque, New Mexico.  I have always known the what: an artist residency in the place I feel an ineffable pull; Morocco, a compelling crossroads of culture and history. Port city of Tetouan is a transition place where Europe and Africa meet. It is a new artistic frontier beckoning a tribe of artists, and I am one of them. This isn’t just a dream: it is my destiny. And I need your help to embark on this soul enriching residency. Join my campaign, and discover through this art journey what can be found in a desert of secrets.

Artist residencies are a common practice among artists to fully immerse themselves into their work without daily distractions. I am honored to have been accepted into the Green Olive Arts Artist Residency in Tetouan, North Africa, February 1-28, 2016.  I join a group of international artists to become part of a larger whole; a band of artists and storytellers weaving a connection between cultures. Within the context of “Convergence,” the theme of this residency, we will uniquely describe our various artistic disciplines through the discovery of new palettes, imagery, and narratives, which can only be found in the medina, a labyrinth of Moroccan culture. Our intensive collaborative adventure culminates with train travel to the Marrakesh Biennial, a premier global art event.

The Work:  The goal of this journey is to fully immerse myself in art practice by expressively sketching and drawing the sites and people, documenting conversations through poetry, collecting collage items, creating visual journal pages and then working from these notes back at the residency atelier to begin larger mixed media paintings and drawings on paper. At the heart of my work I am a story teller weaving connections and creating relationships through word and imagery and in this case, from my ongoing dialogue with the people and spaces of Morocco. My work depicts archetypal signs and symbols and I look forward to expanding my artistic vocabulary through the rich colors, history and sacred geometry of Islamic Art and Morocco’s architecture, not dissimilar to the adobe structures of the American Southwest Desert. I expect to complete some large pieces, but mainly anticipate generating a new artistic direction for when I return to my homeland desert studio where the ongoing dialogue will continue by bringing back the expression of another place.

The Journey:  I depart for Tangier on January 27th and will sketch there for three days. On January 31st, I arrive in Tetouan for the Artist Residency roughly an hour drive from Tangier. Our time for the next 3 weeks will be spent in the studio sharing and exchanging with the other 9 artists in the residency, but also on small excursions: to meet local artisans and learn about their crafts, figure drawing from a live model in traditional Moroccan Dress, panel discussion with the art department at the University, side trips to Chefchaouen, the blue city. Breakfasts and lunches are included in the Residency fee, but I am on my own for dinners, many of which I look forward to cooking! Our final five days we travel by train to Marrakesh for the Marrakesh biennial. I will then stay in Marrakesh a few days to paint and sketch. Next, an overnight camel ride into the Sahara to Fez. Then a day in Fez to sketch Islamic architecture. Finally, back to Tetouan to gather my gear and depart again from Tangier.

The Exchange: Goals and Perks

My goal is to raise $10,400.00 to pay for my Residency at Green Olive Arts for the month of February 2016 as well as two extra weeks of travel to Tangier, Marrakesh, and Fez.  

  • 2900.00 Green Olive Artists Residency

  • 1200.00 roundtrip airfare

  • 400.00 Travel Insurance

  • 3500.00 covers extra baggage fees, shipping home of artwork and supplies, extra daily personal expenses, meals/food shopping and personal purchases, Camel Ride in the Sahara, overnight in Fez, extra days in Marrakesh, purchasing of Morocco perks for you.

  • 400.00 art supplies

  • 2000.00 meet my household needs while I am traveling: mortgage payment and bills

     

This is where you come in: by supporting my art residency, you share in the boon of an artistic journey. So take a look at the levels of what you can financially give on the right side of this page! When you fund this campaign, I will refund your gift with tokens of appreciation and soulful souvenirs from the journey such as hand written postcards from Tetouan, sketches from the coast, drawings from the Red city of Marrakesh, even an online sketching course to begin your own Art Journey- from the comfort and safety of home!!

I know that not everyone is financially prepared to fund this kind of campaign, but you can support what I'm doing in other ways! Please share my campaign and get the word outon social media - Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, etc. The more people who know about this campaign, the more people I get the chance to share this adventure with!

Perks:

In Gratitude for your support of this campaign, I'm offering some Perks that will connect you to this experience in a meaningful way.  They include:

    • Hand-picked souvenir items such as a collection of purchased postcards, Moroccan key chains, etc.
    • Handwritten postcards sent from Morocco.
    • Original Art Postcards
    • Original sketches and drawings made on site.
    • Online workshops and workbooks teaching you how to create your own travel journal.
    • Original paintings inspired by my journey in Morocco


    Thank you for making this dream possible, Juliana Coles

    “One’s destination is never a place, but a new way of seeing things.” – Henry Miller

  • “Travel is more than the seeing of sights; it is a change that goes on, deep and permanent, in the ideas of living.” – Miriam Beard
