depart for Tangier on January 27th and will sketch there for three
days. On January 31st, I arrive in Tetouan for the Artist Residency
roughly an hour drive from Tangier. Our time for the next 3 weeks will be spent
in the studio sharing and exchanging with the other 9 artists in the residency,
but also on small excursions: to meet local artisans and learn about their
crafts, figure drawing from a live model in traditional Moroccan Dress, panel
discussion with the art department at the University, side trips to Chefchaouen, the blue city. Breakfasts and lunches are included in the
Residency fee, but I am on my own for dinners, many of which I look forward to
cooking! Our final five days we travel by train to Marrakesh for the Marrakesh
biennial. I will then stay in Marrakesh a few days to paint and sketch. Next, an
overnight camel ride into the Sahara to Fez. Then a day in Fez to sketch
Islamic architecture. Finally, back to Tetouan to gather my gear and depart
again from Tangier.
The
Exchange: Goals and Perks
My goal is to raise $10,400.00 to
pay for my Residency at Green Olive Arts for the month of February 2016 as well as two extra weeks of travel to Tangier, Marrakesh, and Fez.   

2900.00 Green
Olive Artists Residency
1200.00 roundtrip airfare
400.00 Travel
Insurance
3500.00 covers
extra baggage fees, shipping home of artwork and supplies, extra daily personal
expenses, meals/food shopping and personal purchases, Camel Ride in the Sahara,
overnight in Fez, extra days in Marrakesh, purchasing of Morocco perks for you.
400.00 art
supplies

2000.00 meet
my household needs while I am traveling: mortgage payment and bills


 


This is where you come in: by supporting my art residency, you share in the
boon of an artistic journey. So take a look at the levels of what you can financially give on the right side of this page! When you fund this campaign, I
will refund your gift with tokens of appreciation and soulful souvenirs from
the journey such as hand written postcards from Tetouan, sketches from the
coast, drawings from the Red city of Marrakesh, even an online sketching course
to begin your own Art Journey- from the comfort and safety of home!!
I know that not everyone is financially
prepared to fund this kind of campaign, but you can support what I'm doing in
other ways! Please share my
campaign and get the word outon social media - Facebook,
Instagram, Twitter, etc. The more people who know about this campaign, the more
people I get the chance to share this adventure with!


Perks:In Gratitude for your support of this campaign, I'm offering some Perks that
will connect you to this experience in a meaningful way.  They include:


 Hand-picked souvenir items such as
     a collection of purchased postcards, Moroccan key chains, etc.
 Handwritten postcards sent from
     Morocco.
Original Art Postcards
Original sketches and drawings
     made on site.
Online workshops and workbooks
     teaching you how to create your own travel journal.
Original paintings inspired by my
     journey in Morocco





Thank you for making
this dream possible, Juliana Coles
“One’s destination is never a place, but a new way of
seeing things.” – Henry Miller

“Travel is more than the seeing of sights; it is a change that goes on,
deep and permanent, in the ideas of living.” – Miriam Beard

story:
My Project - Here goes!

This project is for my final degree show in June, which will then end my time at university! The reason I'm using Indiegogo is to raise funds for my final piece as I'm hoping to go out with a bang, but I won't be able to achieve my goal without some help!

I plan to make 1-3 giant teddy bears to act as interactive art, along side a CRT Monitor playing a film that I've made, on loop. The plush teddy bears will be larger than the average person (over 6ft tall) and anyone will be able to hug, kick, jump and relax on them over the entire run of the exhibition.

To create these giant teddy bears I will need a lot of cardboard/paper, fabric, stuffing, thread, weights and patience; 5 out of 6 of those will require money! Which is hopefully, where you guys come in...

My practice this past year has been based around the question "Is it morally right to use animals for our own gain?". This could mean anything, from guide dogs to help the disabled, to elephant riding for our entertainment. I have volunteered with police and domesticated dogs in England to see the differences in how they are treated. I was also lucky enough to get a bursary and extend my research further by going to Thailand. I volunteered with the mistreated dogs over there, which really changed the path I was on with my project. I was also lucky enough to spend a week with elephants, which informed my practice even further, helping me to gain research that I wouldn't have been able to attain had I only stayed in England.

After many months of research, the main thing that kept cropping up - time and time again - was how animals are used for human profit. To demonstrate this, for my final piece I am creating teddy bears to reflect how children use toys for their own entertainment and pleasure, before dismissing them when they are no longer of use. Whilst observing our societal relationships with animals, it was brought to light just how entitled we think we are as a species to use animals all around the world for our own gain.

My hope for this piece is to create an elephant, sheep and dog teddy bear - all filled with feathers, wool and generic stuffing. This is to represent another way we use animals, even if we can't see it. Once I finish making these teddies I will 'hurt' them in all the places I saw the animals hurt on my volunteering courses. 

The degree show will run from 12th - 23rd June 2017 in the SIA Gallery, Sheffield, UK. 

Last but not least, if for whatever reason I have leftover money from these donations, I won't be profiting! Instead, I will split the money between 3 animal charities that I have linked below:

http://www.seashepherd.org

https://www.animalaid.org.uk

http://www.animalhopeandwellness.org 

Risks and challenges

Challenges: 
*Getting all three teddies finished in time - I have a very strict timetable that I am following which even allows extra time before the show if needed, but many unexpected things can happen so this is why I have said 1-3 teddies.

*Finding strong enough thread - I have asked many opinions from tutors and friends that have worked in the fashion industry what the best thread could be as well as the strongest stitch. I have also experimented with different threads and stitches to make sure it goes smoothly.

*Having things go wrong which could cause delays - I have allocated extra time for this main reason as you can never expect things to go right 100% of the time.

Risks: 
*Working from my own templates that I created - I have tested them out on smaller scales so it should work out fine as long as I factor in correct notches and seams.

*Being able to fit them through doors - I won't stuff the bears to be stiff so fitting them through by squeezing should work out fine.

*Having them break throughout the exhibition from too much interaction - I will be there with a needle and thread through out the exhibition whenever needed just incase someone does get over excited and hurts the teddies.

A little about me

I was born in Ascot, a town in the South of England. I have loved all types of art since primary school but I really started to thrive in Year 9 when I found my love for combining colour and 3D art. 

At 16 years old, upon finishing secondary school, I moved into a student house in York to study a national extended diploma in art and design at college. I had the best time whilst I was there and I feel that this is where I started to find my purpose and style in art.

After college, I studied 3D Design: Ceramics at Staffordshire University, but sadly it wasn't the right course for me so I left after my first term, determined to find somewhere that was right for me!

9 months later, I enrolled on to the Fine Art course at Sheffield Hallam University, beginning again. I fell in love with the freedom they gave me to explore any medium and subject I wanted! Without this freedom I really don't think I'd be able to go into the art world like I have and for that, I am forever grateful.

story:
Hi there!

We met at Texas State University and continued to go to Grad school together at the Rhode Island School of Design.

As an artist couple, it can be difficult to stick together as opportunities arise for each of us, often in different locations. One way we've learned we can stick together is through collaboration.

We applied to a number of artist residencies for this summer, and are pleased to announce that we have been accepted into The Wassaic Project in Wassaic, New York and the Starry Night Residency in Truth or Consequences, New Mexico. Additionally, Suzy has been accepted into the Studios at Mass MoCA in North Adams, Massachusetts. We are so appreciative to the organizations that have faith that we can make great things together.

Michael's work consists of multi-flatscreen animations inserted within painted structures. The animations address social concerns pertaining to Latino ethnic groups as well as other minorities living in the United States. Through multiple frames, he classifies and portrays the family customs and social conflicts within the diverse population in the US.

Suzy's work  finds connections between the treatments of beings based on race, gender, and species. She examines the complexity of what it means to portray a subject or an object, and critiques historical nude painting through a subversion of the figure. The work manifests as hybrids of painting and sculpture feeding on the middle ground and removing the urge to create binaries.

As you can see, there is a definite overlap in each of our practices. Together we have created public art installations, one at the Roger Williams National Memorial in Providence, RI, and another with Michael R. Leon at the Rhode Island School of Design Museum, and we hope to work together this summer to create more mixed media installations that please both of our conceptual and technical frameworks.

We need your help in order to attend our summer residencies!!

*When you donate, there are a number of items you may receive, including a limited edition collaborative print for only $50!

Where will your money go?

$4,000 Residency fees

$500 Art supplies

$500 Road trip gas (by the way, it looks like we're going to be driving everywhere!)

So please consider donating to our fundraiser so that we (and you!) may have to the opportunity to see what comes of our two practices joining together.

*Other ways you can help: Please share our campaign with your family and friends who might be interested!

THANK YOU!

-Michael Menchaca and Suzy Gonzalez

michaelmenchaca.com

suzygonzalez.com

story:
“I have been impressed with the urgency of doing. Knowing is not enough; we must apply. Being willing is not enough; we must do.” ~ Leonardo da Vinci

Ciao!  Benvenuto!

We are the Iron Monkeys, and we want to teach you to blacksmith.


A decade ago we started building art together, and we are celebrating our Tennaversary by doing something a little different - we are bringing a fully functional blacksmith shop to Black Rock City.


(Pssss….hey you.  Hold this hammer for a minute.)



What is Piazza di Ferro?

Piazza di Ferro is a place to explore.


(Thanks for holding that hammer.  Could you go put this piece of round bar in the forge? If you want gloves they are over there.)


The entire Piazza will be a 95’ diameter courtyard, with the shop situated dead center. The shop  is a 30’ diameter hexagon with 10 ’tall  walls. Doors and windows will provide entry ways, line of sight and fold-out workspace which will allow people to engage with blacksmithing on a number of levels.  Additionally inside there will be racks of steels for the construction of on playa projects along with the tool of the trade: anvils, hammers, forges, chisels, cutters, trail mix, grinders, more hammers, punches, saws and safety gear.


Surrounding the shop will be a community gathering space where people can sit down in the warmth of the propane flame effects, watch the activity within the shop, play with the popular Zen Fire Gardens, or simply engage with others.

 

You too can blacksmith.


The Iron Monkeys came together around the desire to make art with metal.  We believe that anyone can blacksmith and that is the sweaty, dirty gift we want to give this year.  


(Ok.  Now we are going to taper and scroll the round bar.  Come over here by the anvil and take this hammer back.  I’ll get the piece out of the forge)


To make this project happen we need tools and steel.  Lots of steel.  Your donation will help us purchase material and build the things we need to have a mobile shop. This includes making a couple of small forges, some bending tools, chisels, refurbishing hammers, setting up anvils, and making tongs.


Unfortunately, as awesome as we are, we don’t have the skills or time to build all the tools we need to blacksmith in the desert, so we need to purchase a lot of things. Most of our day-to-day hardware (anvils and hammers and tongs OH MY) will not be leaving the shop in Seattle.  It needs to stay and be ready for our return to regular operations.


The more tools, workspace and materials we have the more people we can get into the shop to try their hand at our craft.


And while the Piazza is destined for Black Rock City, we are already making plans to quite literally set up shop in Seattle and offer the citizens of our home town the same opportunity we are offering to the fine folks of Black Rock City.  At the end of Burning Man we will be in possession of a mobile blacksmithing education set-up and look forward to sharing the art of blacksmithing with as many people as possible.


With all that in mind we turn to you, friends, in the hope that you might feel inspired and motivated to contribute a few dollars to our vision. We really can’t do it without you.


In return, we are offering some fantastic gifts and handmade keepsakes, which will forever be a memento of your engagement in bringing bad ass artistic projects like Piazza di Ferro to life. Even a few dollars - the cost of an afternoon cup of coffee - will help our mission greatly.



Grazie!


There is no chance we would be celebrating a decade of Iron Monkeyness this year without the support of folks like you.  Every time we have asked our people for help you have come through in spades.  


We hope that Piazza di Ferro inspires you as much as it inspires us.


(Check out this beautiful scroll we made!  Thanks so much for the help.  Are you ready to learn something new?)


Can’t wait to see you in the shop.


Perks and rewards:

Pendants (top to bottom) Twisted, Leaf, Hammer

(We were asked about size of the pendants, quarters and last years Monkey Tail pendent added for reference)



The Spiked Pendent Chandalier


F"unicorn" horn earrings


Bottle openers


Triad scroll necklace


Railroad Spike Letter opener


The current working version of the 2016 ten year shirts


Working version of the Bandana logo



More pictures soon

Working version of the Bandana logo




More pictures soon

story:
Short Summary

I'm Riya, an 18 year old, pansexual and gender non-conforming writer, artist, and activist. Despite being young, I've found a deep passion for finding ways to raise love and awareness, both in my personal life, and in my work as in artist. About a year ago, I worked with Shameless Photography Studio as a birthday present to myself. Unbeknownst to me at the time, it would jump start a career in modeling, have me featured in Bust and People Magazine, and extend my reach as an activist and speaker. 

Besides the entrepreneurial gains of the shoot though, I also achieved a new sense of confidence, which seemed to be contagious! Through sharing my photos, I was told my many people, especially other disabled LGBT+ youth, that it was rejuvenating to see someone like them looking and feeling beautiful, valuable, and alive.

As I came to talk to these people, and also reflect on my own experiences, I realized a vital piece that was missing from the representation of LGBT spectrum people. We rarely are shown in our complexities. When we are also disabled, people of color, people of size, women, lower-class, or any other marginalized identity, this is especially true. Even today, with great projects like #itgetsbetter showing us it's possible to live a happy life, we aren't shown the extent and variety of amazing personalities and experiences our community has.

This especially extends to history, where LGBT+ people were often closeted, erased, or not recorded and talked about as a part of our past. This felt a little harrowing, seeing as from a young age we're told our history is what makes us. This led me back to Shameless, as their vintage photography allowed us to recreate the past in the sense, and showcase our current stories to honor those of the past, and bring our spectrum and spirit to life. 

This led me to the idea of creating a Photo Book, featuring vintage style photography and writing of people on the LGBT spectrum, that represents the complexity of their humanity in the ways they wish to show it to the world. I hope that as it did with my photo, visual representation will allow people to embrace and visualize themselves as whole people, the way they want and deserve to be seen.

What We Need & What You Get

The money I'm raising is to be used between three sections. About $400 goes to the models, and transportation for them. It's incredibly important to me to make sure I can share the stories of people who would be unable to expend resources and time on this project, without compensation. It's also important to me to value art, presence, stories, and emotional labor, as we value other work.

About $2,400 is going to shooting the models. This is to supplement the cost of three full days of shooting, to support the studio, who have consistently brought their own artistic talents, resources, and amazing spirits to the project. Shameless Photography is run by talented women entrepreneurs, with a focus on helping people achieve confidence through modeling. Carey and Sophie, the photographers I'm working with, are both passionate activists involved in the community, as well, and their passion comes through in their work.

The remainder of the money is going to publishing. If we reach our goal that will produce 51 books. 50 being sold online, and at LGBT+ events. The last one will be given away based on a raffle, to allow LGBT+ youth, or others who may not be able to afford a copy, access to the final project.

If the entire goal isn't reached, less copies will be printed initially. Alternatively, if above the goal is reached, more copies will be given away to people who couldn't otherwise access them.

Some perks for contributing to the project include extra photos that won't be shown in the book, poetry collections, digital copies of some of the writing (both some features in the book and others) pre-release of the book, and more beautiful art!

The Impact

The aim of this project is to increase the representation of LGBT+ people of all sorts, and the variety and complexities of our lives. Representation allows both non-LGBT+ people to see us as more fully as human beings, and for LGBT+ people to further embrace themselves and their value to the world. 
Often times media today has a very homogenous (definition: consisting of parts all of the same kind - added for accessibility) depiction of us. They rarely expand into LGBT+ people who aren't thin, white, abled, celebrities. Even when they showcase those narratives, they often either make sexuality and gender the only part of their identity, or they erase it completely. 
What I aim to do, with this project, is project our own stories into the world. Stories that show our sexualities and genders interplaying with many other aspects of ourselves, and our lives. I aim to celebrate the whole beings of ourselves and others who read the book. 
Most importantly, I aim to remind LGBT+ people, especially youth, that there is, always has been, and always will be, other people with lives like their own that experience joy, love, passion, and hope within these complexities of their existence. 

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk to the project is my own disability. Because of hospital visits and chronic fatigue, working on the project has somewhat of a flexible timeline. Luckily, most of the work can be done from bed, and I'm overwhelmingly passionate about this project. I find working on it healing, and while not having an exact date, I feel confident I will release the book early next year.

Another risk of course, is not reaching the goal monetarily. As explained earlier, the first cut will be the number of copies initially produced. If demand allows, we can always bring the book back into production and allow more copies to be sold. If one of the other segments isn't fully covered however, I don't want to allow the people working hard on this project to go unpaid, or unrewarded for their work. I'll most likely try other ways of raising money, in person and through selling second hand clothing and my art. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money, but you're interested in the project, there are other ways you can help. Sharing this fundraiser and project, through word of mouth, social media, or email is an incredible help. Indiegogo has a share button that's hoping to be used! 

You can also like me on Facebook at Riya B, where you can contribute suggestions, and receive updates on the project!

Despite being young, I've found a deep passion for finding ways to raise love and awareness, both in my personal life, and in my work as in artist. About a year ago, I worked with Shameless Photography Studio as a birthday present to myself. Unbeknownst to me at the time, it would jump start a career in modeling, have me featured in Bust and People Magazine, and extend my reach as an activist and speaker. 
Besides the entrepreneurial gains of the shoot though, I also achieved a new sense of confidence, which seemed to be contagious! Through sharing my photos, I was told my many people, especially other disabled LGBT+ youth, that it was rejuvenating to see someone like them looking and feeling beautiful, valuable, and alive.
As I came to talk to these people, and also reflect on my own experiences, I realized a vital piece that was missing from the representation of LGBT spectrum people. We rarely are shown in our complexities. When we are also disabled, people of color, people of size, women, lower-class, or any other marginalized identity, this is especially true. Even today, with great projects like #itgetsbetter showing us it's possible to live a happy life, we aren't shown the extent and variety of amazing personalities and experiences our community has.
This especially extends to history, where LGBT+ people were often closeted, erased, or not recorded and talked about as a part of our past. This felt a little harrowing, seeing as from a young age we're told our history is what makes us. This led me back to Shameless, as their vintage photography allowed us to recreate the past in the sense, and showcase our current stories to honor those of the past, and bring our spectrum and spirit to life. 
This led me to the idea of creating a Photo Book, featuring vintage style photography and writing of people on the LGBT spectrum, that represents the complexity of their humanity in the ways they wish to show it to the world. I hope that as it did with my photo, visual representation will allow people to embrace and visualize themselves as whole people, the way they want and deserve to be seen.   What We Need & What You Get The money I'm raising is to be used between three sections. About $400 goes to the models, and transportation for them. It's incredibly important to me to make sure I can share the stories of people who would be unable to expend resources and time on this project, without compensation. It's also important to me to value art, presence, stories, and emotional labor, as we value other work.
About $2,400 is going to shooting the models. This is to supplement the cost of three full days of shooting, to support the studio, who have consistently brought their own artistic talents, resources, and amazing spirits to the project. Shameless Photography is run by talented women entrepreneurs, with a focus on helping people achieve confidence through modeling. Carey and Sophie, the photographers I'm working with, are both passionate activists involved in the community, as well, and their passion comes through in their work.
The remainder of the money is going to publishing. If we reach our goal that will produce 51 books. 50 being sold online, and at LGBT+ events. The last one will be given away based on a raffle, to allow LGBT+ youth, or others who may not be able to afford a copy, access to the final project.
If the entire goal isn't reached, less copies will be printed initially. Alternatively, if above the goal is reached, more copies will be given away to people who couldn't otherwise access them.
Some perks for contributing to the project include extra photos that won't be shown in the book, poetry collections, digital copies of some of the writing (both some features in the book and others) pre-release of the book, and more beautiful art!   The Impact
The aim of this project is to increase the representation of LGBT+ people of all sorts, and the variety and complexities of our lives. Representation allows both non-LGBT+ people to see us as more fully as human beings, and for LGBT+ people to further embrace themselves and their value to the world. 
Often times media today has a very homogenous (definition: consisting of parts all of the same kind - added for accessibility) depiction of us. They rarely expand into LGBT+ people who aren't thin, white, abled, celebrities. Even when they showcase those narratives, they often either make sexuality and gender the only part of their identity, or they erase it completely. 
What I aim to do, with this project, is project our own stories into the world. Stories that show our sexualities and genders interplaying with many other aspects of ourselves, and our lives. I aim to celebrate the whole beings of ourselves and others who read the book. 
Most importantly, I aim to remind LGBT+ people, especially youth, that there is, always has been, and always will be, other people with lives like their own that experience joy, love, passion, and hope within these complexities of their existence. 
    Risks & Challenges The biggest risk to the project is my own disability. Because of hospital visits and chronic fatigue, working on the project has somewhat of a flexible timeline. Luckily, most of the work can be done from bed, and I'm overwhelmingly passionate about this project. I find working on it healing, and while not having an exact date, I feel confident I will release the book early next year.
Another risk of course, is not reaching the goal monetarily. As explained earlier, the first cut will be the number of copies initially produced. If demand allows, we can always bring the book back into production and allow more copies to be sold. If one of the other segments isn't fully covered however, I don't want to allow the people working hard on this project to go unpaid, or unrewarded for their work. I'll most likely try other ways of raising money, in person and through selling second hand clothing and my art. 
    Other Ways You Can Help If you can't donate money, but you're interested in the project, there are other ways you can help. Sharing this fundraiser and project, through word of mouth, social media, or email is an incredible help. Indiegogo has a share button that's hoping to be used! 
You can also like me on Facebook at Riya B, where you can contribute suggestions, and receive updates on the project!

story:
Grey Hand Press

Grey Hand Press is a Collaborative Editioning Studio and Publisher of Fine Art Prints established by Claudia Husband and Chris Hagen in 2016. Our primary goal as an institution is to foster the presence of lithography in our region, and to keep the art of the print a relevant, valuable, and appealing medium to artists, galleries and the wider community.

Though Brisbane has a rich printmaking community with a number of dedicated studios, our press will be the first in the greater Brisbane area to act as publishers: approaching a curated range of artists to produce new print-based work.

In addition to our focus on lithographic mediums, we also work with artists in book arts and intaglio printmaking. We are already working with artists in both publishing and contract printing, and have received overwhelming support from our community; but we need some help to keep the momentum going.

In our current political climate, there are so few opportunities available (ie. zilch) that support an artistic undertaking like ours. We are reaching out to our beloved friends, family, colleagues (and your friends and families and colleagues) to assist us in building this exciting new venture. Every single person who donates (yes, everyone!) will not only be contributing to our studio and helping us to build artists’ portfolios, but will also receive a token of our gratitude. Just make sure to hit "claim" when donating, so we know where to send it to! 

 

 

How your donations will be used:

  • Assisting us in securing a studio location that will not only allow us to be autonomous, but also be properly equipped and compliant; and provide a comfortable space for our artists to work in
  • Acquisition and re-location of our lithography press and equipment
  • Purchasing of studio materials, such as paper, ink, solvents, bookbinding materials, acid baths, shelving and storage
  • Seeking out new artists and potential buyers, including galleries and exhibiting opportunities.
  • Facilitating workshops in our studio, and spreading the printmaking love!

 

Our Goal

Our minimum goal is $2,500, but we are hoping to raise more, to really get things kickstarted –

Whether you can donate $5 or $500, every little piece is valuable and will be used toward the studio in some way –  $5 will get us a crayon holder or some tusche brushes, and $500 will enable us to buy a ream of paper and a can or two of ink.  

If you are unable to donate at this time (don't worry, we get it!) we would appreciate your assistance in sharing our campaign around and spreading the printmaking love!

 

What We Do 

Printmaking is a unique medium classified by the transferal of ink from one surface to another. The creation of a print begins with a ‘matrix’ (eg. lino, wood, copper, zinc, aluminium or stone) with which the image is made on. Ink is then applied to the matrix and transferred to the final surface - usually paper - by applying pressure.

 

Printmaking's most unique feature is its ability to produce multiples. Unlike digital or reproductive printing, there is no distinction between 'copies' or 'originals' - each impression is one and the same, as every single print within the edition is made by hand and approved by the artist.

 

What about Lithography?

Lithography is derived from the Greek origins “litho” - stone, and “graphy” - writing. Lithography is a planographic printmaking process, which means that the image is created from the flat surface of a limestone or aluminum matrix. Unlike etching or linocut, there is no need for incision or direct physical alteration of the surface in order to create the image, as the technique is reliant upon the principle that oil and water do not mix.

Lithography was originally termed “chemical printing” by its creator, Alois Senefelder in 1798, who discovered the process after he wrote his shopping list on a slab of Bavarian limestone with a greasy crayon. After applying chemicals to the drawing, he discovered that by keeping the stone wet with a film of water, he would be able to roll a greasy ink into the drawing and thus pull multiple impressions.

Lithography became a crucial process to the printing industry. It was used initially for commercial purposes, primarily in the reproduction of manuscripts, plays and maps; and it wasn’t until 1803 that artists began to adopt the process for their own work (such as Alphonse Mucha, Toulouse Lautrec and Picasso). Lithography revolutionised the commercial printing industry with the process of offset lithography being born directly from the traditional lithography printing process. This was vital in allowing the mass distribution of printed material to the public, particularly during the 1950s and 60s. The development of digital printing – which has become ubiquitous with the 21st century, was born from the offset printing press (and thus, the lithographic medium!)

Over the years, lithography began to lose its popularity as a fine art medium, and traditional lithography started to become obsolete. Thanks to many determined printmakers – specifically June Wayne, who founded the prestigious Tamarind Lithography Workshop (now known as the Tamarind Institute) in 1960, lithography has re-gained its momentum and status in the printmaking world.

Due to the direct drawing process, lithographs have a very unique aesthetic that can rarely be achieved in other processes. It allows the artist to draw with the immediacy with which one might normally draw with, while also allowing the freedom of image manipulation. Printmaking allows the printer to make multiples; experiment with colour, form and materials; combine imagery; and develop images to multiple dimensions.

Clinton Barker Spewing Out Seeds of Faith 2016, Lithograph on Magnani cotton rag paper

 

“Publisher of Fine Art Prints"?

Collaborative printing practice allows artists to produce images in specific print mediums by working with printmakers. There are two traditional models of collaborative printmaking – publishing and contract printing. In publishing projects, a studio will invite an artist to create a new edition of original prints. The studio takes the risk of covering the material and labour costs and in exchange, retains half of the final prints for sale, distribution and exhibition. Publishing allows the studio to act as a representative of the artists, promoting, exhibiting and selling their work; and therefore benefiting both the artist and the studio.

Contract printing (or 'custom' printing) is typically initiated by an artist who approaches a studio with the desire to create a series of prints in their chosen print medium. In this case, the studio only keeps a few of the prints for their own collection and exhibition, and the artist receives the entire edition.

Working with a collaborative print studio has benefits for many types of artists - printmakers and non-printmakers alike. Artists who work in other mediums such as painting, drawing, sculpture, design and digital media are able to produce work in a new medium guided by the expertise of the studio printers. Many artists who are already experienced printmakers themselves will often approach an editioning studio to create a suite of work in a print medium outside of their current oeuvre. This allows artists to create work in an exciting new medium, without the expense or inconvenience of learning the method themselves.

 

The Perks

Every person who donates will receive something in return from us – no matter how big or small. We would also like to thank you on our website, unless you would prefer to be anonymous – just let us know!

If you would like to receive one of these perks from us, make sure to "CLAIM" when donating so that we know where to send it to! 

 

$1 - $15        Listing of thanks on our website

$15                Small printed token of gratitude

$50                Small postcard sized editioned print by Chris or Claudia

$100              Small 30x30cm (approx.) Editioned print by Chris or Claudia; or Voucher to attend a 1-day printmaking class at our studio

$250              Large  50x50cm (approx) Editioned print by Chris or Claudia; or voucher toward a 2-day printmaking class at our studio

$500              Editioned print by one of Grey Hand Press’s artists

$1500+         Folio of editioned prints by Grey Hand Press artists completed in 2017

 

If you would like to talk about sponsorship, or get involved in another way, or just plain want to talk to us about our studio, please get in touch with us!

story:
Contribute to SubSurface and get a T-shirt, posters, original art and other perks

SubSurface is an annual gathering of graffiti artists and muralists in Indianapolis, Indiana. Since 2002 the event has been organized by FAB Crew in collaboration with local and regional artists, attracting standout graffiti artists from all corners of the United States. 

 

Learn more about this year's event at SubSurfacegraffiti.com.

You can see every wall from 2002 through 2011 at our SubSurface Graffiti Flickr page.

 

For our 10th Anniversary and we're creating a fuller experience for the artists, all of whom are now friends. For the first time we're working with the local art community to help shed some light on SubSurface, which we see as a cultural treasure for Indianapolis.

 

Although we have achieved a great deal on our own, it has become clear that we'll need some help to do what we have in mind for 2012. It is our ultimate goal to raise funding to properly compensate our guest speaker and musical performers as well as to help provide or offset expenses to featured artists.

 

The Goals and Rewards

We're looking for a grand total of $5,000 by August 13th. Although we have several goals, we have narrowed them to the following

•Fully compensate our guest panel speaker Dave Chino, a world-renowned graffiti artist and documentarian. We intend to fly him from NYC to Indy for 3 days with hotel.

•Cover costs associated with non-painting Subsurface elements. These include processing, printing, transporting and framing a large selection of photography,printing serigraph and digital posters, stickers and other promotional materials.

•Establish resources that will allow us to acquire large quantities of paint and other materials to provide participating artists. This may include travel costs.

•If we manage to get through all of those things and we still have a surplus, we would love to compensate the SubSurface team for the many hours of thought and effort required to make this happen.

 

In return we have a series of unique perks. Everything we're offering has been designed or created by the SubSurface family. Perks range from SubSurface 2012 T-shirts at the Fan Level to original artwork and signed posters at the Funder level. In between you'll find everything from original music to stickers...

Fan = $25

Friend = $100

Family = $500

Funder = $1000

 

The Message

We started doing this for ourselves, the artists behind SubSurface. But it became something that is now about an entire community; and not only the graffiti community. We realized this year that we need to take it to the entire Indianapolis community. After 10 years, it's obvious that we have something special here and we want the city to see it and be blown away. Your contributions will multiply our efforts and help us present something unforgettable to the city, and to our friends.

 

If you cannot contribute financially but you wish to get involved, we are still looking for wall locations. We have a good collection of walls but with top-tier artists calling every day, we need all the help we can get. Spread the word that we're looking for blank canvases in Fountain Square.

story:
Who We Are

We are the members of the Saskatchewan Regional Burning Man group from Saskatchewan, Canada. Our region includes everyone from veteran burners to "birgins", to people who are interested in the Burning Man culture but haven't yet attended.

Last year, we were fortunate to have our art project, Burning Sheaf, included in the first Circle of Regional Effigies (CORE) project. It was a fantastic experience for everyone involved, and we're extremely excited that Saskatchewan has been accepted into the CORE project again this year!

SCORE 2011 was funded by people within our circle. Not only do we want to make it easier to donate this year, but we want to make it easier for people in and out of province (and country!) to support our project.

What We're Doing

This year's project features several themes important to Saskatchewan history -- the wild plains bison (and their disappearance), wheat and farming, and (of course) fire.

Bison were crucial to the survival of native peoples in the prairies of Canada, and were nearly hunted to extinction by white settlers, who supplanted the natural prairie with crops of wheat and barley. Saskatchewan is considered the wheat province, but many of the effects of farming, including the forced relocation of native tribes and the failing Indian Act, have yet to be addressed. The project's vision is to juxtapose the themes of bison and wheat, and set them on fire as a literal way of burning the stereotypes and colonial history still present in Saskatchewan today.

"Bison Field" will be a twenty foot tall structure composed of environmentally friendly materials which will be burned along with the other CORE effigies at the 2012 Burning Man festival.

What We Need & What You Get

We're looking for funding to help support the costs of the project -- everything from purchasing the wood and the lights to transporting the project the 2000km to the playa to making sure that our entire perimeter team can be seen in the dark  and during any dust storms (bright tshirts were integral to this last year).

Here's a breakdown of our budgeted costs for the project:

  • Wood
  • Lighting
  • Community involvement
  • Transportation of the project
  • Uniforms

What happens if we fundraise more than our goal? Anything raised over and above our goal goes directly back into the project. (Where before there was lighting, there is now super lighting!)

The Impact

SCORE 2011 was a great experience for Saskatchewan Burners, and was a really great way to solidfy our comparitively small community together on the playa. The 2011 project was our first community art project, and it was a great experience! It's prompted us to think about what it means to be from Saskatchewan, and how important it is to us to be able to share our art at the Burning Man festival.

We want to continue our representation of Saskatchewan at the CORE project by bringing our SCORE 2012 project down to the playa. We've expanded the scope and size of our project this year, and are extremely excited about seeing everything come together.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate your money, how about donating your time? Like our Facebook fanpage, and keep an eye out for the next work bee. 

Please repost our campaign, and like our Facebook page! Also, keep an eye on IndieGoGo for other Burning Man projects you can support -- pARTicipation is a great way to contribute to the event!

Please repost our campaign, and like our Facebook page! Also, keep an eye on IndieGoGo for other Burning Man projects you can support -- pARTicipation is a great way to contribute to the event!

story:
Short Summary

Becoming Our Spaces is a creative collective lead by artist Courtney Surmanek. We are dedicated to opening up communal spaces that encourage expressive freedom.

On August 7 2015, Courtney and her team of artist-facilitators will take part in East End Arts' JumpstART Festival in Downtown Riverhead. Becoming Our Spaces is centered around a sculptural installation of life-sized, vibrantly colored, paper mache arches. Lovingly called "Improvisation Station", this outdoor space will be interactive: one to play in for both young and old. A playful chorus of improvised sound, visual art making and movement will take place, activating the site at designated times. 

Many exciting events and happenings are abound in connection with Becoming Our Spaces. An all-ages workshop will be held at Improvisation Station by Thomas Manuel, Director of the LIU Post Jazz Ensemble, and visionary behind The Jazz Loft in Stony Brook. 

Becoming Our Spaces will also host a special workshop off-site with Riverside Rediscovered. Festival-goers will be invited to join in a creative imagining of what makes a community unique, an extension of the exercises we will exploring in Improvisation Station. Vine & Hops on East Main Street will also be joining Becoming Our Spaces to provide happy hour priced drinks in exchange for a spoken word poem. 

Why's It Important?

Creativity is a key element in building our future and the world we want to see. However, artistic creation is something many of us let go of at an early age. Not good enough, or not born with what we perceive as "talent", we give up on the idea altogether. Well, I'm here to tell you that I'm not a good artist. It takes me hours to get a figure drawn right. The power of the arts isn't in how well you can depict something, but in the motivation behind it. What is good anyway? And if it's "good", is it interesting or worthwhile?

Becoming Our Spaces is asking festival-goers to abandon talent for one evening. We provide the experience, all we ask is that you join us! 

The installation I build in the beginning will look and feel completely different by the end of the festival—covered in new paint, found objects and memories from the people who took part in the experience. With each new person that joins in and contributes through laughter or direct action, the work becomes more meaningful. It's important to me that as you walk away you're able to see the difference not only in the sculptural site, but within yourself. You may be asked to write something down, say something out loud, connect with a stranger, or move your body in a certain way. The key is in the offering. This isn't my project, it belongs to each and every one of you.

With a lil' help from my friends, colleagues, and all giving souls out there...

...we can make this happen! We need your support so we can pay our lovely artist-facilitators for their time and energy, as well as to source and transport materials for the sculptural site, Improvisation Station. We're hoping to raise $1000 ($500 of which will be matched by East End Arts), though if we fall short of our goal, we will still do what we can in order to bring this experience to Riverhead. We want you to know that we appreciate your support, so all of the perks we're offering as part of this campaign will be personal, from handwritten postcards all the way up to a video chat with members of the Becoming Our Spaces team.

And if we exceed our goal...

We will donate the rest of the funds to The Jazz Loft, the incredible organization Thomas Manuel (one of our facilitators) is working on.

The Impact

The JumpstART Festival is an exciting platform for artists and audiences across Long Island to enjoy and celebrate creativity. We believe that improvisation and spontaneous creativity are important for all, young and old. Our artist-facilitators are passionate about their crafts and want to make them accessible to you! Central to our methodology is the approach of providing the audience with the creative agency to become artists themselves. We want you to be a part of this, and we will make every effort in order to ensure that it happens! We have many ideas for how we might continue this project beyond the JumpstART Festival, and are excited to explore them after this first installation.

Risks & Challenges

One of our most significant challenges will be the transportation of the Improvisation Station arches to the grounds of East End Arts. We will be reaching out to our network in order to solve this problem, but renting a truck is also an option we are considering. Becoming Our Spaces does not view this challenge as an obstacle however, but just another step in the process that is creating this space.

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to your support through funding, you can help us by sharing this campaign with your friends and family! This project can only be as successful as our network allows it to be, and by connecting our network with yours, you'll be increasing the support that we will receive in this endeavor! However, the most important way you can help us is by coming to see us this August 7th! We want to engage with you creatively, and we can't do that if we don't see you in Downtown Riverhead!

story:
Hello friends! 

My name is Kazandra Santana.

In 2011 the murder rate in PR had risen to an astronomical figure and I wanted to  shed some light on this issue so I created the golden shoes project. It was a street art installation of 1,136 pairs of shoes painted gold…1 pair for each person that was murdered in 2011. Over 150,000 experienced the installation. 

And I am back at it again. Im doing the golden shoes project in Chicago this year. 

456 people were murdered in Chicago in 2014. Recent articles state we should not be alarmed as homicide rates are flat to last year….but if you look closer at the statistics….people that were shot and wounded increased by 23% AND for 2015, the homicide rate is up from last year from 35 murders to 43 same time last year. 

Why shoes? The soles of the shoes are what separates us from the earth and these peoples souls are what we hope to honor and represent in the installation.  

Why gold? Gold is the one of the oldest and most widely accepted forms of currency. It represents so many things...from capitalism to value to history. In short, we want the color gold to remind us of that which has value (human life)…our citizens....which we are loosing to violence.   

3 GOALS

1. create awareness: we are bombarded with so much information that at times it is hard to grasp the severity of an issue….we cannot change that which we are not aware of. Our hope is to create a visual for the viewer as to what is happening in our communities...in our own back yard.

2. unite communities: a project by the people for the people. For the Golden Shoes Project-Puerto Rico we held workshops in schools, museums, community centers, halfway houses, you name it. The goal is to create bonds, connections between communities and working on a project together does just that. This project gives communities a voice and encouragement to create. We hope to do just that for the people of Chicago. 

3. honor those we lost. these people we lost to violence are not a statistic but humans…with families & friends that now live with the loss of their loved one. We are honoring those lives. We also will be holding a special workshop for family members of actual victims of violence and give them the opportunity to paint the shoes of their loved one themselves. We hope it will be a healing process for them. 

Art is not trivial. By supporting this project  you are saying art is important and can create change. You are encouraging these communities and letting them know that people outside of their community care. 

This project is not funded by any organization or corporation. It is coming to fruition through YOU and me….so WE NEED YOUR FINANCIAL SUPPORT. 

$5,000 is the goal...The money will be used for the materials necessary to do workshops such as: spray paint, glue, glitter, paint trays, paint brushes and other supporting materials such as boxes, trash bags, gloves, website costs, storage and transportation of shoes. 

click donate now. right now. thank you. 

If you cannot contribute, YOU CAN STILL HELP by: 

Donating shoes

Hosting a workshop to paint shoes

Go to a workshop to paint shoes

Share about the Golden Shoes Project on social media

story:
Présentation du projet :

Notre  projet d’exposition mettra en avant plan notre travail à titre de finissants du programme Techniques de métiers d’art offert par le Cégep Limoilou  en partenariat avec la Maison des métiers d’art de Québec, l’École de joaillerie de Québec, l’Institut québécois d’ébénisterie ainsi que l’École nationale de lutherie. En effet, après cette formation technique de 3 ans, nous obtiendrons en mai 2017 notre diplôme d’études collégiales.

L’exposition se déroulera du 7 au 18 juin 2017 au Musée national des beaux-arts du Québec. Elle mettra en valeur des œuvres utilitaires ou d’expression, des œuvres uniques et de série que nous avons créées, nous, les 30 finissants des disciplines suivantes : Céramique, Construction textile, Joaillerie, Lutherie - guitare, Lutherie - violon, Ébénisterie artisanale et Sculpture. Cet évènement d’importance placera à l’avant-scène notre talent, notre créativité et notre leadership. Cette première expérience professionnelle nous offrira un rayonnement significatif pour le lancement de notre carrière.

 

Nous avons besoin de vous!

Nous avons mis en place plusieurs activités de financement afin de combler les besoins financiers pour la réalisation de cet évènement d'envergure. Avec votre aide ainsi que celle de commanditaires et de partenaires, nous espérons amasser plus de 12 000 $ pour notre projet. Jusqu'à maintenant, nous avons récolté plus de 7 000 $.

 

Vous êtes sans le sou, mais souhaitez nous aider?

Si vous ne pouvez pas contribuer financièrement, vous pouvez nous offrir votre soutien en faisant circuler notre projet dans vos réseaux.

 

Quelques-unes des contreparties qui vous sont proposées :

Linge à vaisselle tissé à la main!

 

Calendrier réalisé par les étudiants de lutherie!

 

Bol ou une tasse de céramique fait à la main!

Ensemble de 3 bougeoirs en bois!

Merci de soutenir la relève en métiers d'art!

story:
CONCEPT

 

Creation of a whole sculptural geological era in an olde worlde â€˜greenâ€™ charity-run farm in deepest England.  A kaleidoscope of Scraptorzioc creatures, humanoids and weird, fantastic plant life will colonise wooded ravines and lakes of the Magdalen Project.

 

 

Giant Diatom to float on ponds

endangered microscopic sea creatures from Jurassic era

(this print is one of the perks)

 

 

Situated near the dramatic Jurassic coast of Dorset, the Magdalen Project charity runs a vast range of courses for all ages.  Visited by over 7000 people per year, it specialises in Care Farming, therapeutic effects of contact with nature and farming to disadvantaged, special needs and mental health sufferers. Sustainability is a key principle. (www.themagdalenproject.org.uk) Our transformed landscape will become a part of the whole Magdalen experience from June â€™12.

  

The Scraptorzoic Era will reveal a Lost World - a fantasy fusion of old legends and a new Eden.  Scraptorzoic creatures emerging from giant spawn, bulbous anthills swelling on tall spikes, exotic diatoms floating on ponds, gnarled, writhing growths, tribes of humanoids, skeletal steel goats, totemic constructions, monstrous insects creeping from trees; huge raptors and Hieronymus Bosch-inspired forms to delight visitors. Vibrant colour and translucency. Sci-fi and Jurassic melded.

 

Our sculptural narrative - using retrieved materials including old farm machinery found on site - offers a magical, inspirational, epic experience for all visitors â€“ local and from further afield.

 

                                                                      

 

 

 

Spawn and Scraptoroids

(this print is one of the perks)

 

IMPACT

 

  • Ethos â€“ epic, creative approach to environmental issues: raising awareness of art, utilising discarded stuff around us.
  • Engaging new audiences to explore diverse benefits and natural habitats of the Magdalen Project. 
  • Creating a vibrant, inspiring, sustainable environment, encouraging both children and adults to develop new skills, enjoy eco-adventures and develop a richer understanding of the countryside, its historical and geological heritage. 
  • Interactive participation, inviting young people to contribute creations through a workshop - giving them a sense of ownership over the trail.  The Scraptors will run this workshop in the summer with young people to develop pieces to add to the giant transparent spawn containing scrap embryonic creatures, which will grow as the trail develops.

 

   

Giant Austin Mini Monster and Humanoids made from lawnmower hoppers

(these prints are perks)

 

 

US

 

Founded January â€˜11, the Scraptors www.scraptors.blogspot.com are a group of four collaborative sculptors in South West England specialising in recycled materials. In September â€˜11 we installed a successful Sculpture Trail at Stourhead, Wiltshire (world famous 18th century landscape garden owned by the National Trust - UKâ€™s premier heritage body). See stourhead national trust . We explored themes connected with classical mythology, wildlife and artworks from the house and gardens.  The Trail received fantastic feedback, was well-documented and hailed as â€œAmazing, unexpected, inventive, funny, entertaining and wonderfully sensitive to the environment, each piece shows real care in the way it is placed to add to the interest of its setting...the atmosphere was magical. All around one heard laughter and exclamations of surprise and wonder.â€œ wincanton window .  For more of our media coverage visit: www.scraptors.blogspot.com and see S-J Whiteâ€™s film: Scraptors at Stourhead made by professional film-maker S-J White of whitespace productions on our behalf.

 

 

 

The Scraptors:

 

  •   Paul Boswell www.boswellart.blogspot.com : draws non-stop. Commissions for large-scale wall paintings nationally and internationally, including Helsinki, London, San Francisco and Shanghai.  Collaborates on sculptures with partner Rachel Macleay; plays bass guitar with 'Animals and Men'.  
  •   Fiona Campbell www.fionacampbellart.co.uk : Sculptor. 3-d Wildlife Artist of the Year â€™09 Award, London; Award-winner in Atkinson Gallery Summer Show â€˜11. Exhibits extensively in UK and abroad; commissions include eco site-specific sculptures for Glastonbury/Larmer Tree Festivals, Carymoor Environmental Centre, Somerset, Tamar Valley Centre, Cornwall and Stackpool Park, Worcestershire. 18 years experience teaching art/working within the community.
  •   Rachel Macleay http://www.flickr.com/photos/boswell66:  originally painter of building-based collages (capriccios), creates imagined environments, which inform her approach to sculptural work.  Involved in renovation of buildings from early age.  Part of the Sozo Collective, Birmingham; worked with Paul as the Forge Collective, creating stage sets   for Mark Bruce Dance Company.
  •   Anthony Wilson www.sculpturemad.com : Sculptor/Curator. Curated the Love London Recycled Sculpture Show  at London Zoo in 2008 and London Wetland Centre bird reserve in 2009. Created sculptures for London Zoo, the Environment Agency and Sky Art.  

 

 

 

 

 

 

FUNDING REQUIREMENTS AND YOUR REWARDS

 

We need $15,000 minimum to enable us to realise this ambitious project in full over the next 5-6 months. This is our first funding pledge.  So far, we have been self-funded, gaining some support through sponsorship.  The funds we raise with your help will go towards sourcing redundant machinery, other materials such as rafts for floating sculptures (scrap canâ€™t always be retrieved for free), equipment, installing safety measures and to publicise the event widely.  If we fall short of our target, we will create a scaled down version - depending on available funds.  All donors will get an illustrated personalised certificate.  To view our certificate and selection of drawings as perks, look in our Gallery. We will contact you to clarify which print/s you'd like.

 

All supporters, if they wish, can have their name on a list on our website.  In addition, we offer the listed perks with our thanks.

Exhibits extensively in UK and abroad; commissions include eco site-specific sculptures for Glastonbury/Larmer Tree Festivals, Carymoor Environmental Centre, Somerset, Tamar Valley Centre, Cornwall and Stackpool Park, Worcestershire. 18 years experience teaching art/working within the community. 


  Rachel Macleay http://www.flickr.com/photos/boswell66:  originally painter of building-based collages (capriccios), creates imagined environments, which inform her approach to sculptural work.  Involved in renovation of buildings from early age.  Part of the Sozo Collective, Birmingham; worked with Paul as the Forge Collective, creating stage sets   for Mark Bruce Dance Company.


  Anthony Wilson www.sculpturemad.com : Sculptor/Curator. Curated the Love London Recycled Sculpture Show  at London Zoo in 2008 and London Wetland Centre bird reserve in 2009. Created sculptures for London Zoo, the Environment Agency and Sky Art.  

 
 
 

 
 
 
FUNDING REQUIREMENTS AND YOUR REWARDS
 
We need $15,000 minimum to enable us to realise this ambitious project in full over the next 5-6 months. This is our first funding pledge.  So far, we have been self-funded, gaining some support through sponsorship.  The funds we raise with your help will go towards sourcing redundant machinery, other materials such as rafts for floating sculptures (scrap canâ€™t always be retrieved for free), equipment, installing safety measures and to publicise the event widely.  If we fall short of our target, we will create a scaled down version - depending on available funds.  All donors will get an illustrated personalised certificate.  To view our certificate and selection of drawings as perks, look in our Gallery. We will contact you to clarify which print/s you'd like.
 
All supporters, if they wish, can have their name on a list on our website.  In addition, we offer the listed perks with our thanks.

story:
Malama Pono, a new series of images by photographer Britten Traughber, is scheduled to debut at Jan Brandt Gallery in Bloomington, IL on May 25th, 2013. This campaign is aimed at raising half the funds needed to produce, print, mat and frame the show. 

Since moving to the Big Island two years ago, Britten has become friends with many resilient women, who have shared their stories with her. The images in Malama Pono are based on these stories, creative re-interpretations in which the narrator herself has often modeled for her own story. Anonymous stories, or stories told in secret, have been interpreted using models. 

"Malama Pono" often translates as "It's all good" or in this case "Please Take Care". It is Britten's goal that this work will celebrate the lives of the women who have so graciously trusted their stories to her, while bringing light to the often unspoken hardships and struggles of everyday life in Hawaii. 

Through this campaign I'm aiming to raise half the cost of this show. The other half of my budget (plus travel to the mainland for the show and any unforeseen additional costs) is being covered by my two "real" jobs that have funded this endeavor thus far.

Plans are being made for future exhibits on the mainland, and any amount raised over the goal will go toward creating a traveling show specifically to be shown on the Hawaiian Islands. 

Printing is being done locally on the Big Island. These prints will come on the plane with me to Illinois and be framed shortly before the show opens. All frames, glass and matting will be prepared ahead of time in Illinois by local businesses. After the exhibit the show will be crated and hopefully sent out to its next venue!

Due to the challenges of creating work on an island and presenting it thousands of miles away, I've had to get creative with materials, time and my budget. I believe in the power of this show so much. Please help me share this work with a larger audience & celebrate the stories of these amazing women.  Thank you for your support!

story:
Overview

The DutchMill is an interactive public art piece that will represent the people, culture and art of the Netherlands at the Black Rock Arts Festival (aka Burning Man) as part of the Circle of Regional Effigies, or C.O.R.E. The project seeks to create one of the most familiar symbols of the Netherlands by errecting a large Windmill on the Playa and we feel very proud to have been accepted as a CORE project by the Black Rock Arts Foundation and given an initial grant to get started.

However, the amount of the grant is not enough to make this project and our dream come true! We need funding from people like you to help make this unique art piece happen.

Details of the Project

When people think of the Netherlands one of the most frequent symbols of the country is the windmill. The Dutch people have been embracing man of the 10 Principles of Burning Man such as Radical Inclusion, Community/Civic Responsibility, and Immediacy through working together to reclaim their country from the sea for hundreds of years. As such we feel that a Dutch Mill is the perfect representation of the Dutch Burners and a great fit for our first (of hopefully many) CORE projects.

The project will be designed and built through a collaboration of local Burners and Artists with the actual construction done in the US and will use donated recycled wood as much as possible. We have already partnered with the Reno CORE project and they have graciously offered to allow us to work along side them in Reno.

Appearance

Our project will be a very unique piece on the Playa not only in that it will be a collobartion of work done in two countries, but also in the overall appearance of the piece. Rising out of the baren salt flat dessert will be a structure that is covered in brilliant colors and vibrant lights at night. The outside of the piece will be covered in fabric and be strikingly different from the cutout wood and painted pieces that tradditionally mark CORE projects. This innovative decoration style will not only be unique but serves to solve one of the biggest problems of the project. How can we allow all the artists and participants in our project in the Netherlands help in decorating a piece built in the US? The fabric pieces will allow the art to be done locally and then added to the piece during assembly. The large sheets will be stretched across the panels of the base of the mill.

The structure itself will have an octagon shaped base in tradditonal style.

Below a picture of one of the design drawings:

 

The panels  will be painted in a large abstract mural by Daniella Rubinovitz (http://www.daniellarubinovitz.com/

Beautiful Inside and Out

Our project is not just beautiful on the ouside, but meant to be a place of sanctuary and museum to Dutch art and culture. The inside will be open with a couple of benches so that people can sit and relax with local music played through a very small sound system.

Bike powered

Inside the mill, there will be a bike, connected to the blades of the mill, using a nice piece of Dutch engineering. Anyone can go for a ride and make the mill actually work. Yes, make those blades spin and illuminate the playa!

Shining Bright in the Night

One of the most amazing aspects of Burning Man is the vivid colors and lights at night. Our project will be radicially illuminated in a few ways. Each of the blades will be brightly illuminated in a softly changing flood or color by a strip of LEDs down the entire length. The entire outside will be illuminated with soft white flood lights shining off the colorful fabric sides. 

How your Donation will help!

In order for our project and vision to happen we need help funding it. There are many pieces of the design that will be quite expensive. Here is a quick run-down of the various parts:

  • Wood for construction
  • Lighting and illumination 
  • Fabric / markers / paint 
  • Transporation costs 
  • Interior decorations / materials 
  • Clean up / tools 
  • Contingency
  • Fundraising gifts 

TOTAL ESTIMATE - €3500 

Additionally, many of the people involved in this project will be paying for their own costs to arrive in the United States and stay there for many weeks to build the project. These people are DONATING THEIR OWN TIME AND MONEY and we are not asking you to fund their airfare or time away from their family and friends to make this happen.

What do you get for your donations?

Well in addition to helping make this project happen and sharing it with tens of thousands of festival goers, you will get the following commemorative momentos for various support levels.  NOTE- Donations are accepted in EUROS.

story:
Venø Gård KUNST is a two day International Performance Art Festival on the island Venøy in Selje, Sogn og Fjordane on the 11th and 12th of July 2015. This is the first time the festival will take place. We have invited nine artists from various countries to produce new work for the festival.

Nigel Rolfe (IR), Kurt Johannessen (NO), Abraham Brody (USA/UK), Karianne Stensland (NO), John Court (UK/FI), Katri Kainulainen & Maximilian Latva (FI), Vincent Campos (FR) and István Kovács (HU)  

The funds from this campaign go towards the artist fee.

We believe in the importance of creating an artistic platform to explore new ways of communication and interaction with one another away from mainstream culture; trying to democratize and decentralize art. Not excluding but including the rural districts, sharing and experiencing art and nature together. 

We hope to Kindle, Unite, Nurture and Stimulate Thought through KUNST, which means art in Norwegian.

Norwegian Organisation Number: 9114911273 


The Perks

Nature lover / Nature lover Extreme

Souvenir / Art poster lover 


Ebook of Festival / Festival Art Book

Webcam Art Performance / Personal Performance (New Work!)


We need your help

We contribute the location and our time and we have received funding to cover travel costs, materials and food for 9 artists, but we believe that artists should be paid for the work they do. With your financial help we will be able to pay a minimum fee of £155 per artist which is 20% of what we would like to pay them. In return we will reward you with our gratitude and perks that truly are embeded with sweat, tears, passion and soul.


How the money will be distributed:



£8349 is the bare minimum to make this project happen and we are nearly there as we have received funding from SR Volda AS, Sogn of Fjordane Fylkeskommune, Nordic Culture Fund and Billedkunstnernes Vederlagsfond Prosjektstøtte and are only £1656 from our goal. All we need is your help to make it happen. 

This is the second time we have run a crowd funding campaign, as the first time was not a success, this time we are opting for flexible funding, which means if we do not reach our target we still get the money and you get your perk, if you have selected one.  

 


Other Ways You Can Help

Listed below are items we need for the Festival. We would very much appreciate it if you are able to donate or lend us item(s) for the duration of the Festival.


And of course helping spreading the word would be absolutely fantastic. A good way is to use the INDIEGOGO share tool:

  • Copy the campaign URL and paste it into an email or social media update
  • Click on the Facebook, Google Plus or Twitter icons to share through your social media networks
  • Add a widget to your blog or personal website. Click Embed and then copy and paste the widget code. 


The Artists

Abraham Brody (England / USA) a performer who breaks the boundaries between classical, folk, and contemporary music. He brings the violin into the genre of performance art as a means to deepen contact between performer and public.

István Kovács (Hungary) installations and performances have radiated an almost religious devotion to Nature. This often gives the immediate impression that each of his creations is a kind of prayer rooted in humility and awe. A truly inspired spirituality shines through his work. 

John Court (Finland / England) output includes performance, sculpture and Video, but he considers all his work to be fundamentally concerned with drawing, in that drawing connects the elements of line, movement, space and time.

Karianne Stensland (Norway) works with investigation and reformulation of gender, power and rank. Her work comprise elements of mixed media, often presented through performance, video or installations.

Katri Kainulainen & Maximilian Latva (Finland) are two artists who have recently started performing together, this is what Katri says about it "In performance I am myself. Through performance one can process a part of you, a part that needs to be communicated with. So joint performances are an interesting way of being with someone you are close with… " 

Kurt Johannessen (Norway) to be present in the situation is fundamental for his work. He tries to keep whatever else as open as possible so as not to precondition the possibilities. This is the starting point. At the same time, however, he is concerned with finding situations that can generate qualities that he has not experienced before.

Nigel Rolfe (Ireland) the central contention of his practice is that art making is a live and vital engagement. He studied sculpture and in the 1970’s used the term “Sculptures In Motion” to describe his work using materials across time—long before the term performance was put forward as any descriptor.

Vincent Campos (France) is interested in peoples interaction with his installations and performances. He tries to focus on the relationship between the two and what the audience will experience.


The Location

Olav Venø is the owner of the beautiful island where the festival will take place. The 400 acres of farm has been in the Venø family for more than 400 years. The next generation are working towards ways to share this sublime spot of nature in order to built bridges to culture and the community.


Why Performance art?

Performance art is a form of art that gives the audience a direct connection with the artwork, because the artist and artwork is one. Performance art is a form of expression that is created in the here and now, leading to a intensity in the meeting between the artwork and viewer, which is different from what is created in static art or art that is experienced via a screen. The fact that the viewer becomes part of the creation process of the artwork and in some cases the artwork itself gives a unique attachment to the work. We believe that performance art, when it is experienced, can contribute to an understanding of how art is created. This may be because performance art gives an insight in to the artist’s energy and mind.


Why in Nature?

The nature in Norway is unique and beautiful, but for some of us who live between the hills and mountains, it has become mundane. A performance artist can either help us experience nature anew or intensify the moment. He or she can create a moment that perceptually lasts longer. Our attention has been focused, just like when we look at a beautiful sunset or a unique play of light. It causes us to linger a little longer at a spot seen many times before. Because a human has created the moment, it might help us to think about the interaction between man and nature. We believe these qualities of performance art can help create a better understanding of contemporary art as a hole.


The Staff

Erik Friis Reitan (Norway) will lead the two panel discussions. He is a visual artist working with photography and installation.

Photographic Documentation

Video Documentation


The Organisers

Bjørn Venø is an artist who works with photography, performance and video.

Julia Kröner works in fashion with a strong belief in the importance of Art.

Anita Eide is an artist who has chosen to live on Venøy.

Jessica Venø is the youngest member of our team, specialising in creating events. 

Olav and Elaine Venø are supplying practical support to the festival, such as the the location, housing and making food.




Big Thank YOU!

Warm wishes The VGK Team
